",1362047910,15133304,False,"<p>I implemented a singly linked list in Java. I can reverse a singly linked list and check whether a given list is circular. The interesting thing is I can reverse a circular list, too which is strange and interesting. Does it make sense to be able to reverse a circular list?Actually it should get reversed over and over again right? At the moment my below code is able to reverse a circular list and terminates. Is it correct?</p>

<pre><code>public class ListNode{
    int value;
    ListNode next;  
    public ListNode(int value, ListNode next){
        this.value = value;
        this.next = next;
    }       
    public ListNode next(){
        return next;
    }
    public void setNext(ListNode next){
        this.next = next;
    }
    public int value(){
        return value;
    }
}

public class SinglyLinkedList {

    private ListNode head;

    public SinglyLinkedList(ListNode head){
        this.head = head;
    }

    public void reverse(){
        ListNode current = head;
        head = null;
        while (current!=null){
            ListNode temp = current;
            current = current.next;
            temp.next = head;
            head = temp;
        }
    }

    public static boolean isCircular(SinglyLinkedList list){
        ListNode counter1 = list.head;
        ListNode counter2 = list.head;
        while (counter1!=null &amp;&amp; counter2!=null){
            counter1 = counter1.next;
            counter2 = counter2.next;
            if (counter2.next!=null){
                counter2 = counter2.next;
            } else 
                return false;
            if (counter1 == counter2)
                return true;
        }
        return false;
    }

    public static void printSinglyLinkedList(ListNode head){
        ListNode temp = head;
        while(temp!=null){
            System.out.print(temp.value + "" "");
            temp = temp.next;
        }
        System.out.println();
    }

    public static void main(String[] s){
        ListNode a4 = new ListNode(4, null);
        ListNode a3 = new ListNode(3, a4);
        ListNode a2 = new ListNode(2, a3);
        ListNode a1 = new ListNode(1, a2);
        a4.setNext(a1);

        SinglyLinkedList list1 = new SinglyLinkedList(a1);
        System.out.println(isCircular(list1));
        if (!isCircular(list1))
            printSinglyLinkedList(list1.head);
        list1.reverse();
        if (!isCircular(list1))
            printSinglyLinkedList(list1.head);




    }
}
</code></pre>
",1349049697,0,java reverse circular singly-linked-list,"Reverse Singly Linked List Java, check whether circular",1651561
12666179,"<p>There are operating system primitives that do what you want: <a href=""http://linux.die.net/man/2/mlock"" rel=""nofollow""><code>mlock</code></a> on Unix (of which Ubuntu is but one example¹), and <a href=""http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa366895.aspx"" rel=""nofollow""><code>VirtualLock</code></a> on Windows.  (Ignore the quibbling in the comments over the exact semantics of VirtualLock; they're irrelevant for your use case.)</p>

<p>The Unix primitive requires <code>root</code> privilege in the calling process (some systems permit locking down a <em>small</em> amount of memory without privilege, but you want far more than that).  The Windows primitive appears not to require special privileges.</p>

<p>¹ ""Linux is not UNIX"" objection noted and ignored with prejudice.</p>

",1349050174,2,c# asp.net sql,Datareader not reading return value for unique identity,1424115
12666221,"<p>Databases break object-orientation in a much more fundamental way.  (Or objects break the relational model.  It depends on whether you're a middle tier OO person or a DBA.)  </p>

<p>Relational databases are set based by definition, declarative in nature.  Object-oriented languages are object-instance based.  Making the two work together is difficult because of ""object-relational impedance mismatch"".   This is why you see so many ORM solutions (e.g. TopLink, Hibernate, etc.)  All of them are trying to fool object-oriented programmers into thinking that they only need deal with objects and not worry about relational databases.</p>

<p>However you implement it, I think persistence should be separate from model objects.  I usually put relational code in an interface-based data access layer.  That way model objects don't have to know whether or not they're persisted, and I isolate the CRUD operations in a single package.</p>

<p>As for recommended reading, I'll offer Fowler's <a href=""http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0321127420"" rel=""nofollow"">Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture</a> for your consideration.</p>
",1349050476,12666246,False,"<p>Philosophical question here
When it comes to OOP and databases, specifically, programs where the classes are backed up with databases, what is the best way to approach this? For instance, a team class might have a collection of players. The program would just load all of the team data from the database at startup, do all the manipulation in memory, and then write the database at close. Or is it better to write each data manipulation to the database as changes occur? And if this is the better way, why load the data into memory in the first place?</p>

<p>The other concern is that it seems to me that databases break standard OOP in one important way. With my team class with the collection of players, using OOP, the player class would not need to have a property to hold the team name. The player would get the team name from the team class of which it is a member. Now, to save the player in the database, each player record will have to have a column for the team name (or team id, but that's the same thing).</p>

<p>In other words, if you needed a GetAllPlayers() method, would you make it a member method in the team class, to return from memory all of the players in the collection, or make a static method in the player class to get all of the players from the database? </p>

<p>Anyone got any tips on how to answer these questions?</p>

<p>It's been a while since I have taken a programming class. Anyone know of a good text book that goes into understanding the best approach here?</p>

12666224,"<p>If it helps, I have a <a href=""http://code.google.com/p/java-algorithms-implementation/source/browse/trunk/src/com/jwetherell/algorithms/data_structures/KdTree.java"" rel=""nofollow"">KD-Tree in Java</a> which takes in XYZ as doubles in a inner class called XYZPoint. You could augment the XYZ Point with the time zone data and use X for Longitude, Y for Latitude, and zero for Z. It could at least be a starting point.</p>

<p>You could then use a nearest neighbor (euclidean distance) method, which is already implemented, for the closest time zone to a point.</p>

<p>Also.. for populating the KD-Tree, <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-d_tree#Balancing"" rel=""nofollow"">wikipeda</a> suggests using <a href=""http://code.google.com/p/java-algorithms-implementation/source/browse/trunk/src/com/jwetherell/algorithms/sorts/HeapSort.java"" rel=""nofollow"">HeapSort (my Java implementation linked)</a> and removing the median repeatedly.</p>

12666235,"<p>Starling is a third party library. It is encouraged and funded by Adobe, but it is not part of the Flash platform itself. Therefore, Flash Pro does not use Starling. In other words, there is only one Flash Drawing API, and obviously Flash Pro uses it when creating vector drawings.</p>

<p>The Flash drawing API does not use Stage3D, and does not use GPU hardware acceleration.</p>

<p>However, it is wrong to assume that you <strong>need</strong> to use Stage3D to get good performance on a 2D game. The vast majority of games, including plenty of complicated, high-performance ones, do not. </p>

<p>To understand better what Stage3D is and how it works, I recommend <a href=""http://www.adobe.com/devnet/flashplayer/articles/how-stage3d-works.html"" rel=""nofollow"">How Stage3D works</a>.</p>

12666248,"<p>Per my understanding, each executable object has its own ""lookup scope"":</p>

<ul>
<li>The main executable is usually the first object in the ""global"" lookup scope.   This means that symbols defined in the main executable would override those in dependent shared libraries.  Shared objects that are added using the <code>LD_PRELOAD</code> facility are added to the global lookup scope, right after the main executable.</li>
<li>However, if the shared object being loaded uses the <code>DF_SYMBOLIC</code> flag, then symbol references that originate within that object will look for definitions within the object before searching in the global lookup scope.</li>
<li>Shared objects opened using <code>dlopen()</code> may have their own dependencies.  If the <code>RTLD_GLOBAL</code> flag was not set during the call to <code>dlopen()</code>, these dependencies are added to the lookup scope for that object, but do not affect the global lookup scope.  If the <code>RTLD_GLOBAL</code> flag was passed to <code>dlopen()</code>, then the shared object (and its dependencies) will be added to the ""global"" lookup scope, changing the behavior of subsequent symbol lookups.</li>
</ul>

<p>Ulrich Drepper's guide ""<a href=""http://www.akkadia.org/drepper/dsohowto.pdf"" rel=""nofollow"">How to Write Shared Libraries</a>"" is recommended reading on this topic.</p>
",1349065027,12667490,True,"<p>What is the search order for symbol lookup when resolving dynamic relocations?</p>

<p>When resolving symbols for a shared library does the loader first search in the 'main executable' (to let the main executable override definitions...) or what?</p>
",1349050487,2,linux gcc ld elf binutils,ELF Dynamic loader symbol lookup ordering,562505

var nr = ids[atr]; // now contains 1
</code></pre>

12666253,"<blockquote>
  <p>how can i differentiate between imports and exports</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Easy: any symbol in the dynamic symbol table (in <code>.dynsym</code>) for which <code>.st_shndx == SHN_UNDEF</code> (references special <code>UND</code> section) is an import, and every other symbol is defined and exported.</p>

<p>Note that <code>.symtab</code> doesn't matter and can be completely stripped -- the dynamic loader never looks at it.</p>

",1349050572,1,shared-libraries elf,ELF Imports and Exports,50617
12666255,"<p><strong>This XPath expression selects all (sibling) nodes between the nodes <code>$vStart</code> and <code>$vEnd</code>:</strong></p>

<pre><code>  $vStart/following-sibling::node()
           [count(.|$vEnd/preceding-sibling::node())
           =
            count($vEnd/preceding-sibling::node())
           ]
</code></pre>

<p>To obtain the full XPath expression to use in your specific case, simply substitute <code>$vStart</code> with:</p>

<pre><code>/*/b[. = 'Content Title']
</code></pre>

<p>and substitute <code>$vEnd</code> with:</p>

<pre><code>/*/a[@href = 'javascript:print()']
</code></pre>

<p>The final XPath expressions after the substitutions is:</p>

<pre><code>/*/b[. = 'Content Title']/following-sibling::node()
         [count(.|/*/a[@href = 'javascript:print()']/preceding-sibling::node())
         =
          count(/*/a[@href = 'javascript:print()']/preceding-sibling::node())
         ]
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Explanation</strong>:</p>

<p>This is a simple corollary of the Kayessian formula for the intersection of two nodesets <code>$ns1</code> and <code>$ns2</code>:</p>

<pre><code>$ns1[count(.|$ns2) = count($ns2)]
</code></pre>

<p>In our case, the set of all nodes between the nodes <code>$vStart</code> and <code>$vEnd</code> is the intersection of two node-sets: all following siblings of <code>$vStart</code> and all preceding siblings of <code>$vEnd</code>.</p>

<p><strong>XSLT - based verification</strong>:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;xsl:stylesheet version=""1.0"" xmlns:xsl=""http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform""&gt;
 &lt;xsl:output omit-xml-declaration=""yes"" indent=""yes""/&gt;
 &lt;xsl:strip-space elements=""*""/&gt;

 &lt;xsl:variable name=""vStart"" select=""/*/b[. = 'Content Title']""/&gt;
 &lt;xsl:variable name=""vEnd"" select=""/*/a[@href = 'javascript:print()']""/&gt;

 &lt;xsl:template match=""/""&gt;
     &lt;xsl:copy-of select=
     ""$vStart/following-sibling::node()
               [count(.|$vEnd/preceding-sibling::node())
               =
                count($vEnd/preceding-sibling::node())
               ]
     ""/&gt;
==============

     &lt;xsl:copy-of select=
     ""/*/b[. = 'Content Title']/following-sibling::node()
               [count(.|/*/a[@href = 'javascript:print()']/preceding-sibling::node())
               =
                count(/*/a[@href = 'javascript:print()']/preceding-sibling::node())
               ]
     ""/&gt;
 &lt;/xsl:template&gt;
&lt;/xsl:stylesheet&gt;
</code></pre>

<p><strong>When this transformation is applied on the provided XML document</strong> (converted to a well-formed XML document):</p>

<pre><code>&lt;div class=""post-body entry-content""&gt;
    &lt;a href=""http://www.photourl""&gt;
        &lt;img alt=""Photo title"" height=""333""     src=""http://photourl.com"" width=""500""/&gt;
    &lt;/a&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;div style=""text-align: justify;""&gt;
    Some text&lt;/div&gt;
    &lt;b&gt;More text&lt;/b&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;b&gt;More text&lt;/b&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;ul&gt;
        &lt;li&gt;Numered item&lt;/li&gt;
        &lt;li&gt;Numered item&lt;/li&gt;
        &lt;li&gt;Numered item&lt;/li&gt;
    &lt;/ul&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;b&gt;Content Title&lt;/b&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    Some text
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br /&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br /&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;br /&gt;
    &lt;a href=""javascript:print()""&gt;
        &lt;img src=""http://url.com/photo.jpg""/&gt;
    &lt;/a&gt;
    &lt;div style=""clear: both;""&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
</code></pre>

<p><strong>the two XPath expressions (with and without variable references) are evaluated and the nodes selected in each case, conveniently delimited, are copied to the output</strong>:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;br/&gt;
    Some text
    &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br/&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br/&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
==============

     &lt;br/&gt;
    Some text
    &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br/&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br/&gt;
    Some text(with links and images)
    &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
</code></pre>

12666256,"<p>You definitely don't want to wait for a reply in your onClick() function.  That will cause your program to be unresponsive until the network request comes it (which could very well take ""forever"").</p>

<p>One way to attack this would be to add a signal to your HtmlManager class.  Something maybe called <code>stringReceived</code>.  Then, in your mainwindow class you'd just need to add a line like this:</p>

<pre><code>connect(html, SIGNAL(stringReceived(QString)), ui-&gt;textBrowser, SLOT(setText(QString));
</code></pre>

#endif // MAINWINDOW_H
</code></pre>

<p>mainwindow.cpp - This is the beginning of the problem. If you look down at the ""downloadButton_clicked()"" function, you see that it fetches the html by sending a request. However, the reply isn't recieved before the next line so the text field is set to """".</p>

<pre><code>#include ""mainwindow.h""
#include ""ui_mainwindow.h""

MainWindow::MainWindow(QWidget *parent) :
    QMainWindow(parent),
    ui(new Ui::MainWindow)
{
    ui-&gt;setupUi(this);

}

MainWindow::~MainWindow()
{
    delete ui;
}

void MainWindow::on_addButton_clicked()
{
    if(!ui-&gt;lineEdit-&gt;text().isEmpty())
    {
        ui-&gt;listWidget-&gt;addItem(ui-&gt;lineEdit-&gt;text());
    }
    else
    {
        qDebug() &lt;&lt; ""Input field is empty."";
    }
}

void MainWindow::on_actionExit_triggered()
{
    //doesn't do anything right now
}

void MainWindow::on_removeButton_clicked()
{
    if(ui-&gt;listWidget-&gt;currentItem()) //If an item is selected
    {
        delete ui-&gt;listWidget-&gt;currentItem();
    }
    else
    {
        qDebug() &lt;&lt; ""No selection"";
    }
}

void MainWindow::on_downloadButton_clicked()
{
    if(ui-&gt;listWidget-&gt;currentItem()) //If an item is selected
    {
        html.fetch(ui-&gt;listWidget-&gt;currentItem()-&gt;text());
        ui-&gt;textBrowser-&gt;setText(html.str);
    }
    else
    {
        qDebug() &lt;&lt; ""No selection"";
    }

}
</code></pre>

<p>htmlmaneger.h</p>

<pre><code>#ifndef HTMLMANAGER_H
#define HTMLMANAGER_H

#include &lt;QObject&gt;
#include &lt;QDebug&gt;
#include &lt;QtNetwork&gt;
#include &lt;QNetworkReply&gt;
#include &lt;QNetworkAccessManager&gt;
#include &lt;QString&gt;


class HtmlManager : public QObject
{
    Q_OBJECT
    public:
        HtmlManager();
        void fetch(QString Url);
        QString str;

    public slots:
        void replyFinished(QNetworkReply* pReply);

    private:
        QNetworkAccessManager* m_manager;
};

#endif // HTMLMANAGER_H
</code></pre>

<p>htmlmanager.cpp - Once the reply is received, it stores the html in the QString ""str"" </p>

<pre><code>#include ""htmlmanager.h""

HtmlManager::HtmlManager()
{
    m_manager = new QNetworkAccessManager(this);
    connect(m_manager, SIGNAL(finished(QNetworkReply*)), this, SLOT(replyFinished(QNetworkReply*)));
}
void HtmlManager::fetch(QString Url)
{
    m_manager-&gt;get(QNetworkRequest(QUrl(Url)));
    qDebug() &lt;&lt; ""Sending network request."";
}
void HtmlManager::replyFinished(QNetworkReply* pReply)
{
    qDebug() &lt;&lt; ""Recieved network reply."";
    QByteArray data=pReply-&gt;readAll();
    str = data;
}
</code></pre>

12666259,"<p>If marquerChangement() is not being called, there can only be two possible reasons.  First is that the QTextEdit represented by curr_text_edit never emits a signal (in other words, perhaps you've got the wrong QTextEdit?).  </p>

<p>Another possibility is that your call to <code>connect</code> failed.  This signal/slot connection is done at runtime, not compile time.  Failures here typically just get printed to stdout, and then the program goes happily on its way.  Check your application output to see if you get a message about a signal or a slot not found.</p>

12666262,"<blockquote>
  <p>is it a good idea to run each task on a separate thread</p>
</blockquote>

<p>It sounds like a good idea to split your program into threads since the 2 tasks can work asynchronously and concurrently.  The 1st thread could be downloading at the same time the 2nd one is uploading.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>how do I lock the folder when it's used by either task to avoid interference?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I wouldn't do a lock at all.  I'd have your 1st thread read a file from the server, write it into the folder, and then add a <code>FileToSend</code> object (or maybe just a <code>File</code> object) to a <a href=""http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/BlockingQueue.html"" rel=""nofollow""><code>BlockingQueue</code></a>.  So instead of looking at the directory, your 2nd thread would just be waiting on the <code>BlockingQueue</code> for files to be sent to the server.  The <a href=""http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/LinkedBlockingQueue.html"" rel=""nofollow""><code>LinkedBlockingQueue</code></a> class should work well for this.  The <code>BlockingQueue</code> takes care of the locking for you.</p>

<p>If you <em>do</em> need to share a lock then you could just inject a lock object into your two threads:</p>

<pre><code>private final Object folderLock = new Object();
...
new Thread(new Downloader(folderLock)).start();
new Thread(new Uploader(folderLock)).start();
...
</code></pre>

<p>A good pattern would be to define an <code>addFileToUpload(File fileToUpload)</code> method on your <code>Uploader</code> class.  Then your <code>Uploader</code> can decide what to do with it.  The <code>BlockingQueue</code> could then be local to the <code>Uploader</code></p>

<pre><code>Uploader uploader = new Uploader();
// pass the uploader into the downloader
new Thread(new Downloader(uploader)).start();
new Thread(uploader).start();
</code></pre>
",1349050993,12666285,True,"<p>I have a Java client (client server app) that does two main things: (1) listen to server to receive files and save them to a local folder and (2) watch that folder for changes and send changes to the server. I want to run each in its own thread. First, is it a good idea to run each task on a separate thread. Second, how do I lock the folder when it's used by either task to avoid interference?</p>
",1349050716,4,java multithreading client-server,Multithreading my client Java program,179850
12666265,"<p>If you return an array from a method, you need to either capture the values as separate things or use the result as arrays are supposed to be used. What you're seeing is the default <code>Array#to_s</code> method output.</p>

<p>Capture separately:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;% img_tag, descripion = my_helper_method(data) %&gt;
&lt;%= link_to(img_tag, description) %&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>You can also use the array as-is if the return values can be passed in as arguments to another method using the splat (<code>*</code>) operator:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;%= link_to(*my_helper_method(data)) %&gt;
</code></pre>

12666268,"<h2><em><a href=""http://jsbin.com/agutuk/3/edit"" rel=""nofollow"">jsBin demo</a></em></h2>

<pre><code>&lt;div class=""box""&gt;This is DIV #1 :) &lt;/div&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>Add a class <code>.box</code> to all your 8 elements and do:</p>

<pre><code>jQuery(function($){

  var replaceText = $('#replace').text();
  var memorizeText = '';

  $('.box').on({
      mouseenter: function(){
          memorizeText = $(this).next('.box').text();   // memorize text
          $(this).next('.box').text(replaceText);
      },
      mouseleave: function(){
          $(this).next('.box').text( memorizeText );    // restore memorized text
      },
      click: function(){
          $(this).next('.box').text( replaceText );
          $(this).off('mouseleave mouseenter');
      }
  });

});
</code></pre>

12666272,"<p>This is simply because ECMAScript 262 3rd edition specified a somewhat odd optional exception for unusual eval() calls. See the last part of this section of the specification:
<a href=""http://bclary.com/2004/11/07/#a-15.1.2.1"" rel=""nofollow"">http://bclary.com/2004/11/07/#a-15.1.2.1</a></p>

<p><strong>If value of the eval property is used in any way other than a direct call (that is, other than by the explicit use of its name as an Identifier which is the MemberExpression in a CallExpression), or if the eval property is assigned to, an EvalError exception may be thrown.</strong></p>

<p>I'm not entirely sure what the reasoning behind this sentence is, but as you see both Opera's Carakan engine and Safari's ES engine have chosen to implement an exception if a reference to eval is defined on some object and called from there.</p>

<p>Later editions of the ECMAScript standard have removed this (having an <strong>optional</strong> exception in a spec is a very bad idea in the first place) and Opera will be adapting in some future Carakan-version. It's already been fixed internally due to these questions on StackOverflow ;)</p>
",1349857849,12815136,True,"<p>Some forms of indirect <code>eval</code> fail in Opera, and, I'm told, in Safari. </p>

<pre><code>[eval][0]('')
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
  <p>Unhandled Error: eval called with invalid this object</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Notice that it fails when evaluating an empty string... as far as I can tell it should return <code>undefined</code>.</p>

<p>Other forms, like <code>(0,eval)('')</code>, seem to work fine.</p>

<p>Running the examples from this <a href=""http://kangax.github.com/jstests/indirect-eval-testsuite/"" rel=""nofollow"">test suite</a> by kangax, I see several forms that fail with the ""invalid this object"" message in Opera, but not Chrome or Firefox. </p>

<p>Can anyone explain why this happens? What dictates this behavior? It seems intentional, does it adhere to some part of the standard I don't know about?</p>

<p>Related -- <a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9107240/1-evalthis-vs-evalthis-in-javascript"">SO discussion</a> about indirect vs. direct eval.</p>

<p>Also -- <a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12666447/why-is-0-eval-not-treated-as-indirect-in-opera"">Why is (0 || eval) not treated as indirect in Opera?</a></p>

12666278,"<p>If you're running Kubuntu, PyQt will be installed by default. Most linux distros will have one of  PyGtk or PyQt installed by default. WxPython was most likely installed in your Ubuntu box as a dependency for some other package in your system. </p>

<p>If your target market is Linux, you can just create a deb or rpm package and that'll take care of the dependencies for your application.</p>

<p>For Windows and Mac(and even linux if you're so inclined) you could bundle the python interpreter with your application and it's libraries into a native executable format such
as .exe or .elf using libraries like <code>cx_freeze</code>, <code>py2exe</code> and <code>py2app</code>. Once this is done, your user will not have to install <code>python</code> or any of your libraries.</p>

12666282,"<p>Ideally, the long-term solution is to patch HtmlAgilityPack to use a heap-stack instead of the call-stack, but that would be an undertaking too big for me. I've temporarily lost my CodePlex account details, but when I get them back I'll submit an Issue report on the problem. I also note that this issue could present a Denial-of-Service attack vulnerability to any site that uses HtmlAgilityPack to sanitize user-submitted HTML - a crafted overly-nested HTML document would cause the w3wp.exe process to die.</p>

<p>In the meantime, I figured the best way forward is to manually override the maximum thread stack size. I was wrong in my earlier statement that a bigger stack-size means that all threads automatically consume that memory (it seems memory pages are allocated for a thread stack as it grows, not all-at-once).</p>

<p>I made a copy of the <code>&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;</code> page and ran some experiments. I found that my program failed when the stack size was less than <code>2^21</code> bytes in size, but a maximum size of <code>2^22</code> succeeded - that's 4MB and in my book passes as an ""acceptable"" hack... for now.</p>
",1349053228,12666448,True,"<p>I'm using HtmlAgilityPack to parse roughly 200,000 HTML documents.</p>

&lt;/ol&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>There are roughly 10,000 <code>&lt;li&gt;</code> elements nested like that. Due to the way HtmlAgilityPack parses HTML it causes a <code>StackOverflowException</code>.</p>

<p>Unfortunately a StackOverflowException is not catchable in .NET 2.0 and later.</p>

<p>I did wonder about setting a larger size for the thread's stack, but setting a larger stack size is a hack: it would cause my program to use a lot more memory (my program starts about 50 threads for processing HTML, so all of these threads would have the increased stack size) and would need manually adjusting if it ever came across a similar situation again.</p>

",1349050956,1,html-agility-pack stackoverflow,Work-around a StackOverflowException,159145
12666284,"<p>I think they're saying that when they use that notation (sum of a big-O), it means there's a single O(i) function (call it <code>f(i)</code>), and then the expression refers to the sum from 1 to n of that function.</p>

<p>This isn't the same thing as if there were <code>n</code> different functions (call them <code>f_1(i)</code> to <code>f_n(i)</code>), each of which is <code>O(i)</code>, and then the expression refers to the sum of <code>f_1(1) + f_2(2) + ... + f_n(n)</code>. That latter thing is not what the notation means.</p>
",1349051606,12666329,False,"<p>I came across this passage on <a href=""http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NLngYyWFl_YC&amp;pg=PA47"" rel=""nofollow"">page 47</a> of <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_Algorithms"" rel=""nofollow""><em>Introduction to Algorithms</em> by Cormen et al.</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The number of anonymous functions in an expression is understood to be equal to the number of times the asymptotic notation appearrs. For example in the expression:</p>
  
  <p>Σ (<em>i</em>=1 to <em>n</em>) O(<em>i</em>)</p>
  
  <p>there is only a single anonymous function (a function of <em>i</em>). This expression is not the same as O(1) + O(2) + ... + O(<em>n</em>), which doesn't really have a clean interpretation.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>What does this mean?</p>
",1349050987,1,algorithm complexity big-o clrs,What does this passage from CLRS mean?,13005

12666291,"<p>You can't hash lists, only immutable things.  Although you could define a <code>__hash__</code> method for some extension of the <code>list</code> object, the reason behind this logic is that if you were to look something up in a dictionary, you would expect the entries' names not to change.  Similarly, in python, the keys must be immutable.  As another answer said, use a <code>tuple</code> instead.</p>

12666300,"<p>For the data from your sample you can do it with a trivial pair of nested loops:</p>

<pre><code>var list = new List&lt;int&gt;{1,2,3,4,5,6};
var res = new List&lt;int&gt;();
for (int i = 0 ; i != list.Count ; i++) {
    for (int j = i+1 ; j != list.Count ; j++) {
        res.Add(list[i]*10+list[j]);
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>For more complex data, you can use a string concatenation trick:</p>

<pre><code>var list = new List&lt;int&gt;{98,76,54,32,10};
var res = new List&lt;int&gt;();
for (int i = 0 ; i != list.Count ; i++) {
    for (int j = i+1 ; j != list.Count ; j++) {
        res.Add(int.Parse(string.Format(""{0}{1}"", list[i], list[j])));
    }
}
</code></pre>

12666303,"<p>Instead of calling <code>root.iterchildren</code>, use <code>order.iterchildren</code>, where <code>order</code> iterates through <code>&lt;order&gt;</code> elements:</p>

<pre><code>for order in root.xpath('//order'):
    modlist = []
    for element in order.iterchildren('carType'):
        modlist.append (""%s"" % (element.get('value')))

    for element in order.iter('upgrade'):
        modlist.append (""%s"" % str.upper((element.get('type'))))
    # report grand total for order
</code></pre>

",1349051176,1,python xml-parsing lxml,Performing Function Operations on One .xml Item (and Its Children) at a Time with lxml,190597
12666306,"<p>For the count</p>

<pre><code>select COUNT(*) Total
from
(
    select e.*,
        rn = row_number() over (partition by e.subid order by c.cdate desc),
        first_model = coalesce(c.phone_model, e.phone_model)
    from [P_ENROLLMENT] e
    left join [ENROLLMENT_CHANGES] c on c.subid = e.subid
) x
where rn=1 and first_model = 'iPhone 3'
</code></pre>

<p><hr>
For all the records</p>

<pre><code>select *
from
(
    select e.*,
        rn = row_number() over (partition by e.subid order by c.cdate desc),
        first_model = coalesce(c.phone_model, e.phone_model)
    from [P_ENROLLMENT] e
    left join [ENROLLMENT_CHANGES] c on c.subid = e.subid
) x
where rn=1 and first_model = 'iPhone 3'
order by subid
</code></pre>
",1349052226,12666370,True,"<p>In the Enrollment_Changes table, the phone model listed is the phone the subscriber changed FROM on that date.</p>

<p>If there is no subsequent change on Enrollment_Changes, the phone the subscriber changed TO is listed on the P_Enrollment table</p>

<p>For example, subscriber 12345678 enrolled on 1/5/2011 with a RAZR.  On 11/1/2011 he changed FROM the RAZR.  You can see what he changed TO with the next transaction on Enrollment_Changes on 05/19/2012.  </p>

<p>How would you find the Count of subs that first enrolled with the iPhone 3? </p>

<p>Here is the code I have for creating the tables</p>

<p>Create Tables: TBL 1</p>

<pre><code>USE [Test2]
GO

/****** Object:  Table [dbo].[P_ENROLLMENT]    ******/
SET ANSI_NULLS ON
GO

SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER ON
GO

CREATE TABLE [dbo].[P_ENROLLMENT](
    [Subid ] [float] NULL,
    [Enrollment_Date] [datetime] NULL,
    [Channel] [nvarchar](255) NULL,
    [Region] [nvarchar](255) NULL,
    [Active_Status] [float] NULL,
    [Drop_Date] [datetime] NULL,
    [Phone_Model] [nvarchar](255) NULL
) ON [PRIMARY]

GO
</code></pre>

<p>TBL 2</p>

<pre><code>USE [Test2]
GO

/****** Object:  Table [dbo].[ENROLLMENT_CHANGES]     ******/
SET ANSI_NULLS ON
GO

SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER ON
GO

CREATE TABLE [dbo].[ENROLLMENT_CHANGES](
    [Subid] [float] NULL,
    [Cdate] [datetime] NULL,
    [Phone_Model] [nvarchar](255) NULL
) ON [PRIMARY]

GO
</code></pre>

12666319,"<p>Think about what <code>Invite.objects.values('email_address')</code> returns?  Definitely not what the <code>send_mail</code> function accepts (a list of email addresses).</p>

12666320,"<p>In Java, there are a number of ways of accomplishing this.  One way is to use any of the <a href=""http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/locks/Lock.html"" rel=""nofollow""><code>Lock</code></a> objects which has a <code>tryLock(...)</code> method which allows you to wait for the lock for a certain amount of time.  It returns <code>true</code> if it was able to acquire the lock or <code>false</code> if it timed out.  <a href=""http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/locks/ReentrantLock.html"" rel=""nofollow""><code>ReentrantLock</code></a> may be a good choice here.</p>

<pre><code>private final Lock lock = new ReentrantLock();
...

if (lock.tryLock(1L, TimeUnit.SECONDS)) {
   try {
      // we were able to lock
   } finally {
      // always unlock in a finally
      lock.unlock();
   }
} else {
   // trying to lock timed out without locking
}
</code></pre>

<p>After some discussion in comments, I now understand that you have existing <code>synchronized</code> methods that you'd like to wait for only for a certain amount of time.  Unfortunately, there is no way to do this in Java with the <code>synchronized</code> keyword.</p>

12666322,"<p>Use SphinxSE
<a href=""http://sphinxsearch.com/docs/current.html#sphinxse-overview"" rel=""nofollow"">http://sphinxsearch.com/docs/current.html#sphinxse-overview</a></p>

<p>Then would be</p>

<pre><code>SELECT * FROM mysql_table
JOIN (SELECT id FROM sphinx_index WHERE query='keyword') AS match_table
ON match_table.id = mysql_table.id
</code></pre>

<p>Although </p>

<pre><code>SELECT * FROM sphinx_index INNER JOIN mysql_table USING (id) WHERE query='keyword'
</code></pre>

<p>is shorter and more concise. <strong>And</strong> better maintains the order of results. </p>

<p>Where 'sphinx_index' is a SphinxSE table, which points to underlying sphinx index. </p>

",1349051525,0,mysql subquery sphinx,Mixed MySQL and Sphinx queries,65548
12666326,"<p>There are several problems with your code.</p>

<p>In the sender:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>How do you allocate <code>file_buffer</code>? What if the file is bigger than the buffer? (Probably this is not causing the problem at hand.)</p></li>
<li><p>You only check to see if the return value from <code>fread</code> is <code>&lt;= 0</code>. In fact, if an error or EOF occurs, the return value can be any value less than the full size of the file. (Probably this is not causing the problem at hand.)</p></li>
<li><p>You pass <code>strlen(file_buffer)</code> instead of <code>file_size</code> to the <code>sendto</code> system call. <code>strlen</code> looks for NUL bytes which the file may or may not contain. It probably doesn't contain any, since you say it's a text file.</p>

<ul>
<li>If the file contain at least one NUL byte the packet will be truncated before the first NUL byte and you will not transmit the full contents of the file.</li>
<li>If the file contains no NUL bytes, <code>strlen</code> will scan beyond the end of the file as read into the buffer. Either your program will crash because <code>strlen</code> scans into unallocated memory addresses, or you will send additional garbage past the end of the file.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>In the receiver:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>You ignore the return value from <code>recvfrom</code> which is the length of the payload of the packet that was received. After that, there is no way for you to know how much data you received.</p></li>
<li><p>When you <code>fwrite</code> the result, you pass <code>sizeof(file_buffer)</code> as the size instead of the actual amount of data that was received. This is a fixed value (<code>BUFSIZE</code>) which is probably bigger than your file. The file written on disk will contain garbage beyond the end of the file.</p></li>
</ul>
",1349099540,12674640,True,"<p>I am running into problems when I try to transfer a file between the simple server and client applications that I have written. The file gets transferred successfully, but the file size is different at the receiving side (server side).

On the server side, I use recvfrom() to store this and use fwrite() to write it into another file. But when I check the size of the file, it is much bigger. Also I am not able to open it even though it is supposed to be a text file. 
Can you give me some pointers as to where I might be going wrong? Also is this the best way to send files over sockets? Are there better methods to send files?</p>

<p>Thanks  </p>

<pre><code>//Writing code to open file and copy it into buffer

        size_t file_size = ftell(fp);
        fseek(fp, 0, SEEK_SET);
        if(fread(file_buffer, file_size, 1, fp)&lt;=0)
        {
            printf(""Unable to copy file into buffer! \n"");
            exit(1);
        }

        if(sendto(sock, file_buffer, strlen(file_buffer), 0, (struct sockaddr *) &amp;serv_addr, serv_len)&lt;0)
        {
            printf(""Error sending the file! \n"");
            exit(1);
        }
        bzero(file_buffer, sizeof(file_buffer));
</code></pre>

<p>Code on the server side to receive the file</p>

<pre><code>//Receiving file from client
        char file_buffer[BUFSIZE];
        if(recvfrom(sock, file_buffer, BUFSIZE, 0, (struct sockaddr *) &amp;client_addr, &amp;client_addr_size)&lt;0)
        {
            printf(""Error receiving file."");
            exit(1);
        }

        char new_file_name[] = ""copied_"";
        strcat(new_file_name,file_name);
        FILE *fp;
        fp = fopen(new_file_name,""w+"");
        if(fwrite(file_buffer, 1, sizeof(file_buffer), fp)&lt;0)
        {
            printf(""Error writing file! \n"");
            exit(1);
        }
</code></pre>
",1349051558,1,file sockets udp,File size differs when sending over UDP,675129
12666330,"<blockquote>
  <p>Which operand determines the bit width that the operation is performed with, or is it the larger of the two?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>For the bit-shifts, it's the left operand (the one to be shifted) that determines the type that the operation is performed with. If the integer promotions convert it to <code>int</code> or <code>unsigned int</code>, the operation is performed at that type, otherwise at the type of the left operand.</p>

<p>For the comparison, the result of the shift may then be converted to the type of the other operand. In your example code, the integer constant <code>1</code> has type <code>int</code>, hence the shift would be performed at type <code>int</code>, and the result of that converted to <code>unsigned long long</code> for the comparison. Casting works, since the result has a type that is not changed by the integer promotions, as would using a suffixed literal <code>1ull</code>.</p>

<p>For the other listed operations, the arithmetic operations (as for comparisons), the type at which the operation is performed is determined by both operands as follows:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Otherwise, the integer promotions are performed on both operands. Then the following rules are applied to the promoted operands:</p>
  
  <ul>
  <li>If both operands have the same type, then no further conversion is needed.</li>
  <li>Otherwise, if both operands have signed integer types or both have unsigned integer types, the operand with the type of lesser integer conversion rank is converted to the type of the operand with greater rank.</li>
  <li>Otherwise, if the operand that has unsigned integer type has rank greater or equal to the rank of the type of the other operand, then the operand with signed integer type is converted to the type of the operand with unsigned integer type.</li>
  <li>Otherwise, if the type of the operand with signed integer type can represent all of the values of the type of the operand with unsigned integer type, then the operand with unsigned integer type is converted to the type of the operand with signed integer type.</li>
  <li>Otherwise, both operands are converted to the unsigned integer type corresponding to the type of the operand with signed integer type.</li>
  </ul>
</blockquote>
",1349052538,12666391,True,"<p>I am working on a program that mixes 64 bit (for some calculations) and 32 bit (for space saving storage) unsigned integers, so it is very important I keep them sorted out during arithmetic to avoid overflows</p>

    if((1&lt;&lt;shift)&gt;compare)
    {
        do_stuff;

{
    if(((unsigned long long)1&lt;&lt;shift)&gt;compare)
    {
        do_stuff;
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>How do I micromanage the bit width of these things? Which operand determines the bit width that the operation is performed with, or is it the larger of the two?</p>

",1349051612,4,c math bit-manipulation,Bit width of bit shift and arithmetic in C,1011995
12666331,"<p>UIEdgeInsets is a little difficult to wrap your head around, but it <strong>is</strong> the more modern usage.  I will explain the way it works.  Basically, using four offsets, you are dividing your image into 9 slices.  If you want to see an image of what this potentially looks like, have a look at the ""Scaleable area"" section of <a href=""http://radleymarx.com/blog/simple-guide-to-9-patch/"" rel=""nofollow"">this page</a> (Note, it is for Android, but the concept is the same.  Android was just doing it first).  You will notice four lines going through the image.  These will correspond to your four insets.  So your nine sections, from left-to-right and top-to-bottom will be:</p>

<ol>
<li>X: 0 -> Left Inset, Y: 0 -> Top Inset</li>
<li>X: Left Inset -> (Width - Right Inset), Y: 0 -> Top Inset</li>
<li>X: (Width - Right Inset) -> Width, Y: 0 -> Top Inset</li>
<li>X: 0 -> Left Inset, Y: Top Inset -> (Height - Bottom Inset)</li>
<li>X: Left Inset -> (Width - Right Inset), Y: Top Inset -> (Height - Bottom Inset)</li>
<li>X: (Width - Right Inset) -> Width, Y: Top Inset -> (Height - Bottom Inset)</li>
<li>X: 0 -> Left Inset, Y: (Height - Bottom Inset) -> Height</li>
<li>Left Inset -> (Width - Right Inset), Y: (Height - Bottom Inset) -> Height</li>
<li>X: (Width - Right Inset) -> Width, Y: (Height - Bottom Inset) -> Height</li>
</ol>

<p>Sections 1, 3, 7, and 9 are set and will not stretch.<br>
Sections 2 and 8 will stretch horizontally only<br>
Sections 4 and 6 will stretch vertically only<br>
Section 5 will stretch in both directions.</p>

<p>New in iOS 6, you can select a mode.  You can either stretch the stretchable tiles, or repeat them to get the effect that you want (colors, etc should stretch while textures should repeat).</p>

",1349051613,2,iphone ios,iOS Stretchable image on UIButton showing wonky corners,1155387
12666334,"<p>thought I'd leave this up for posterity. The problem is simple, and I'm a fool for not noticing it sooner.</p>

<p>The correct programs I was testing this against used the UDP protocol, and this program is written in TCP. The corrected code is:</p>

<pre><code>public class Lab2Client {
/**
 * @param args[0] == server name, args[1] == server port, args[2] == myport
 */
public static void main(String[] args) {
    //Serverport is 10085, our client is 10086
    try {
        DatagramSocket clientSocket = new DatagramSocket();
        InetAddress IPAddress = InetAddress.getByName(args[0]);
        int portToSend = Integer.parseInt(args[2]);
        System.out.println(""Clent Socket Created"");
        byte[] toSend = new byte[5];
        toSend[0] = 0x12; toSend[1] = 0x34;//Code Number
        toSend[2] = 15;//GroupId, f in hex
        toSend[3] = 0x27;toSend[4] = 0x66;
        System.out.println(""Byte Array Constructed"");

        DatagramPacket sendPacket = new DatagramPacket(toSend, toSend.length, IPAddress, Integer.parseInt(args[1]));
        clientSocket.send(sendPacket);          
        System.out.println(""Sent Request. Waiting for reply...\n"");

        DataInputStream input = new DataInputStream(echoSocket.getInputStream());
        toRecieve can either be an error message, a return of what we sent,
        or a byte stream full of IP info and port numbers.
        the ""heavy"" byte stream is either 4 for IPv4 of 16 for IPv6, 2 bytes for port,
        and the magic number (2 bytes) for a total of 9-20 bytes*/

        byte[] toRecieve = new byte[9];
        DatagramPacket receivePacket = new DatagramPacket(toRecieve, toRecieve.length);
        clientSocket.receive(receivePacket);            
        checkMessage(toRecieve);            
    } //and so on and so forth...
</code></pre>

<p>Thanks to @Serge for the help, though nobody could have answered my question correctly with how I asked it. The byte shifting you suggested was important too.</p>
",1349735156,12790332,True,"<p>I'm starting to write my first Java networking program, and long story short I'm having difficulty making sure that I'm taking the right approach. Our professor has given us a server program to test against this UDP client, but I'm getting some errors I can't seem to squash. Specifically,  I get IO exceptions, either ""Connection Refused"" or ""No route to host"" exceptions. </p>

<pre><code>public class Lab2Client {
/**
 * @param args[1] == server name, args[2] == server port, args[3] == myport
 */
public static void main(String[] args) {
    //Serverport is set to 10085, our client is 10086
    try {
        Socket echoSocket = new Socket(args[0],Integer.parseInt(args[2]));
        System.out.println(""Server connection Completed\n"");
        DataOutputStream output = new DataOutputStream(echoSocket.getOutputStream());
        byte[] toSend = new byte[5];
        toSend[0] = 12; toSend[1] = 34;//Code Number
        toSend[2] = 15;//GroupId
        toSend[3] = 86;toSend[4] = 100;//Port number in Little Endian Order
        output.write(toSend);

        System.out.println(""Sent Request. Waiting for reply...\n"");

        DataInputStream input = new DataInputStream(echoSocket.getInputStream());

        byte[] toRecieve = new byte[]{0,0,0,0,0,0,0,0}; 
        input.read(toRecieve);
        checkMessage(toRecieve);            
    }
    catch (UnknownHostException e) {
        System.err.println(""Servername Incorrect!"");
        System.exit(1);
    }
    catch (IOException e){
        System.err.println(""IO Exception. Exiting..."");
        System.err.println(e);
        System.exit(1);
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>I also have some questions about my implementation regarding receiving messages in Java. I'll be getting a datagram that contains either:</p>

<p><strong>a)</strong> 3 formatting bytes (unimportant to the question) along with an IP and port number </p>

<p>or</p>

<p><strong>b)</strong> 3 formatting bytes and a port.</p>

<p>Is using a DataInputStream the correct way to do this? I know using an array with 9 elements is lazy instead of dynamically allocating one that's either 5 or 9, but right now I'm just trying to get this working. That being said, is there a different approach anyone would suggest for this?</p>

",1349051702,1,cocoa console nsfilehandle keyboard-input,NSFileHandle and scanf not echoing input in Xcode 4.5,794192
12666349,"<p>The compare operators are not defined for std_logic_vector, unless you use non-standard packages. I don't know what your code looked like before you did the changes you mention, but as the code is now you should be able to fix this by changing the line</p>

<pre><code>if (E1&lt;E2) then
</code></pre>

<p>to</p>

<pre><code>if (unsigned(E1) &lt; unsigned(E2)) then
</code></pre>

<p>Note that the ""+"" operator is not defined for std_logic_vector either, so you will have to cast E1 and E2 back and forth between unsigned and std_logic_vector whenever you do arithmetic  operations on them. In your case it would be better to define E1 and E2 as unsigned instead of std_logic_vector, which should work fine as long as your use the numeric_std package and no other non-standard packages from the IEEE library. (such as std_logic_unsigned)</p>
",1349083709,12670640,False,"<p>I am trying to compare two variables:</p>

<pre><code>variable E1, E2 : unsigned(5 downto 0);
</code></pre>

<p>with:</p>

<pre><code>if (E1 &lt; E2) then
lt_val := '1';
end if;
</code></pre>

<p>but that error comes up when I try to compile.</p>

<p>I have no idea what I am doing wrong.</p>

<p>EDIT: Here is the full file, I changed unsigned back to std_logic_vector and used the numeric_std library.</p>

<pre><code>library IEEE;
use IEEE.std_logic_1164.all;
use IEEE.numeric_std.all;

entity FPA is
    port (clk, st : in  std_logic;
          d1      : in  std_logic_vector(15 downto 0);
          d2      : in  std_logic_vector(15 downto 0);
          sum     : out std_logic_vector(15 downto 0);
          rdy     : out std_logic);

end FPA;

architecture behav of FPA is

    type state is (s0, s1, s2, s3, s4, s5, s6, s7);
    signal new_state : state;
    signal norm      : std_logic;
    signal lt, gt    : std_logic;

begin

    process is
        variable curr_state : state := s7;
    begin
        if clk = '1' then
            case curr_state is
                when s0 =&gt;
                    if st = '1' then curr_state := s1;
                    end if;
                when s1 =&gt;
                    curr_state := s2;
                when s2 =&gt;
                    if gt = '1' then curr_state := s4;
                    end if;
                    if lt = '1' then curr_state := s3;
                    end if;
                    if not((lt = '1') or (gt = '1')) then
                        curr_state := s5;
                    end if;
                when s3 =&gt;
                    curr_state := s1;
                when s4 =&gt;
                    curr_state := s1;
                when s5 =&gt;
                    if norm = '1' then
                        curr_state := s6;
                    else
                        curr_state := s7;
                    end if;
                when s6 =&gt;
                    curr_state := s7;
                when s7 =&gt;
                    if st = '0' then curr_state := s0;
                    end if;
            end case;
            new_state &lt;= curr_state;
        end if;
        new_state &lt;= curr_state;
        wait on clk;
    end process;

    process is
        variable E1                : std_logic_vector(5 downto 0);
        variable E2                : std_logic_vector(5 downto 0);
        variable sum_val           : std_logic_vector(15 downto 0);
        variable X, Y              : std_logic_vector(11 downto 0);
        variable SGR               : std_logic_vector(11 downto 0);
        variable rdy_val, norm_val : std_logic;
        variable gt_val, lt_val    : std_logic;
    begin

        -- defaults

        rdy_val := '0';
        case new_state is

            when s0 =&gt;
                sum_val := ""ZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZ"";
                E1      := d1(15 downto 10);
                X       := ""01"" &amp; d1(9 downto 0);
                E2      := d2(15 downto 10);
                Y       := ""01"" &amp; d2(9 downto 0);
            when s1 =&gt;
                if (E1 &lt; E2) then
                    lt_val := '1';
                end if;
                if (E1 &gt; E2) then
                    gt_val := '1';
                end if;
                SGR := X + Y;
            when s2 =&gt;
                if SGR(11) = '1' then
                    norm_val := '1';
                end if;
            when s3 =&gt;
                X  := X ror 1;
                E1 := E1 + ""000001"";
            when s4 =&gt;
                Y  := Y ror 1;
                E2 := E2 + ""000001"";
            when s5 =&gt;
            when s6 =&gt;
                SGR := SGR ror 1;
                E2  := E2 + ""000001"";
            when s7 =&gt;
                sum_val := E2 &amp; SGR(9 downto 0);
                rdy_val := '1';
        end case;

        rdy  &lt;= rdy_val;
        lt   &lt;= lt_val;
        gt   &lt;= gt_val;
        sum  &lt;= sum_val;
        norm &lt;= norm_val;

        wait on new_state;
    end process;

end behav;
</code></pre>

<pre><code>/*
 * ArrayList
 */
package registrosarraylist03xmlteste;

import com.thoughtworks.xstream.XStream;
import java.io.File;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Scanner;

public class RegistrosArrayList03_xmlteste {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        ArrayList listaPessoas = new ArrayList();

        // Menu
        char op;
        do {
            op = menu();
            switch (op) {
                case 'C':
                case 'c': // cadastrar
                    cadastrar(listaPessoas);
                    gravarXML(listaPessoas, ""teste.xml"");
                    break;
                case 'L':
                case 'l': // ler
                    lerXML(""teste.xml"");
                    break;
                case 'E':
                case 'e': // editar
                    Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);
                    MyPessoas p1 = new MyPessoas();
                    System.out.print(""Digite o ID: "");
                    p1.ID = in.nextInt();
                    System.out.print(""Novo nome: "");
                    p1.nome = in.next();
                    System.out.print(""Nova idade: "");
                    p1.idade = in.nextInt();
                    editar(listaPessoas, p1);
                    gravarXML(listaPessoas, ""teste.xml"");
                    listar(listaPessoas);
                    break;
                case 'R':
                case 'r': // remover
                    System.out.println(""O comando Remover ainda nao esta pronto."");
                    break;
                default:
                    System.out.println(""Opcao invalida."");
                    break;
            }
        } while (op != 'S' &amp;&amp; op != 's');
    }

    static char menu() {
        System.out.println(""\n ### MENU ### Selecione uma opcao, digitando a primeira letra."");
        System.out.println(""Cadastrar  Listar  Editar  Remover  Sair"");
        System.out.print(""Opcao: "");
        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);
        return in.next().charAt(0);
    }

    static void cadastrar(ArrayList lista) {
        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);
        MyPessoas p = new MyPessoas();
        // ID gerado automaticamente.
        System.out.print(""Nome: "");
        p.nome = in.nextLine();
        System.out.print(""Idade: "");
        p.idade = in.nextInt();
        System.out.print(""Fone: "");
        p.fone.fone=in.next();
        lista.add(p);
    }

    static void listar(ArrayList lista) {
        System.out.println(""ID - Nome - Idade"");
        for (int i = 0; i &lt; lista.size(); i++) {
            // Obtem os dados da lista MyPessoas
            MyPessoas p = (MyPessoas) lista.get(i);
            System.out.println(p.ID + ""  - "" + p.nome + "" - "" + p.idade);
        }
    }

    static ArrayList lerXML(String filename) {
        XStream xstream = new XStream();
        File arquivo = new File(filename);
        ArrayList listaPessoas = (ArrayList) xstream.fromXML(arquivo);
        listar(listaPessoas);
        return listaPessoas;
    }

    static void gravarXML(ArrayList lista, String filename) {
        XStream xstream = new XStream();
        String xml = xstream.toXML(lista);
        GravarLer Gravar = new GravarLer();
        GravarLer.gravar(xml, filename);
    }

    static void editar(ArrayList lista, MyPessoas p1) {
        System.out.print(""Digite o nome: "");
        for (int i = 0; i &lt; lista.size(); i++) {
            // Obtem os dados da lista MyPessoas
            MyPessoas p = (MyPessoas) lista.get(i);
            if (p.ID == p1.ID) {
                p.nome = p1.nome;
                p.idade = p1.idade;
                break;
            }
        }
    }
//    static void remover(ArrayList lista, MyPessoas p1) {
//        // Obtem os dados da lista MyPessoas
//        MyPessoas p = new MyPessoas();
//        System.out.print(""Digite o ID: "");
//        rmvID = in.nextInt();
//        lista.remove(p);
//    }
}



/*
 * Classe de MyPessoas
 */
package registrosarraylist03xmlteste;

public class MyPessoas {

    public static int lastID = 1;
    public int ID;
    public String nome;
    public int idade;
    public Fone fone;

    // Adiciona numeracao sequencial ao ID.
    public MyPessoas() {
        ID = MyPessoas.lastID++;
    }
}



package registrosarraylist03xmlteste;

public class Fone {

    public String fone;
}



/*
 * Grava e Le registros em arquivos XML.
 */
package registrosarraylist03xmlteste;

import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileWriter;
import java.util.Scanner;

public class GravarLer {

    static void gravar(String xml, String filename) {
        try {
            FileWriter w = new FileWriter(filename);
            w.write(xml);
            w.flush();
            w.close();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            System.out.println(""Erro ao gravar XML: "" + e);
        }
    }

    static String ler(String filename) {
        try {
            Scanner in = new Scanner(new File(filename));
            StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
            while (in.hasNext()) {
                sb.append(in.next());
            }
            in.close();
            return sb.toString();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            System.out.println(""Erro ao ler XML: "" + e);
        }
        return """";
    }

}
</code></pre>

12666355,"<p>This is a recommendation problem. </p>

<p>First the apriori algorithm is no longer the state of the art of recommendation systems. (a related discussion is here: <a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1255663/using-the-apriori-algorithm-for-recommendations"">Using the apriori algorithm for recommendations</a>). </p>

<p>Check out Chapter 9 <strong>Recommendation System</strong> of the below book <strong>Mining of Massive Datasets</strong>. It's a good tutorial to start with.</p>

<p><a href=""http://infolab.stanford.edu/~ullman/mmds.html"" rel=""nofollow"">http://infolab.stanford.edu/~ullman/mmds.html</a></p>

<p>Basically you have two different approaches: Content-based and collaborative filtering. The latter can be done in terms of item-based or user-based approach. There are also methods to combine the approaches to get better recommendations. </p>

<p>Some further readings that might be useful:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>A recent survey paper on recommendation systems:
<a href=""http://arxiv.org/abs/1006.5278"" rel=""nofollow"">http://arxiv.org/abs/1006.5278</a></p></li>
<li><p>Amazon item-to-item collaborative filtering: <a href=""http://www.cs.umd.edu/~samir/498/Amazon-Recommendations.pdf"" rel=""nofollow"">http://www.cs.umd.edu/~samir/498/Amazon-Recommendations.pdf</a></p></li>
<li><p>Matrix factorization techniques: <a href=""http://research.yahoo4.akadns.net/files/ieeecomputer.pdf"" rel=""nofollow"">http://research.yahoo4.akadns.net/files/ieeecomputer.pdf</a></p></li>
<li><p>Netflix challenge: <a href=""http://blog.echen.me/2011/10/24/winning-the-netflix-prize-a-summary/"" rel=""nofollow"">http://blog.echen.me/2011/10/24/winning-the-netflix-prize-a-summary/</a></p></li>
<li><p>Google news personalization: <a href=""http://videolectures.net/google_datar_gnp/"" rel=""nofollow"">http://videolectures.net/google_datar_gnp/</a></p></li>
</ul>

<p>Some related stackoverflow topics:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1407841/how-to-create-my-own-recommendation-engine?rq=1"">How to create my own recommendation engine?</a></p></li>
<li><p><a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1592037/where-can-i-learn-about-recommendation-systems?rq=1"">Where can I learn about recommendation systems?</a></p></li>
<li><p><a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1992508/recommendation-systems-and-the-cold-start-problem?rq=1"">recommendation systems and the cold start problem</a></p></li>
<li><p><a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12778823/web-page-recommender-system"">Web page recommender system</a></p></li>
</ul>

12666361,"<p>The latest version of <code>cgi-lib.pl</code> is dated 1999 and is very out of date. I suggest you use the <a href=""https://metacpan.org/module/CGI""><code>CGI</code></a> library instead, which is almost bound to be installed already on your server and is kept up to date (most recently on August 16 2012)</p>

<p>Your program should look like this:</p>

<pre><code>#!/usr/bin/perl -- 

use strict;
use warnings;

use CGI ':standard';

print header;

print &lt;&lt;END;
&lt;html&gt;
  &lt;head&gt;&lt;title&gt;Hello world!&lt;/title&gt;&lt;/head&gt;
  &lt;body&gt;
    &lt;p&gt;Hello world!&lt;/p&gt;
  &lt;/body&gt;
&lt;/html&gt;
END
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that you can run the program from the command line to see if it compiles and what output it generates. Once you have it working there you can move it to the server</p>

12666362,"<p>First off, the set is not <em>temporary</em>, but <em>local</em>.</p>

<p>Second, the correct way to return it is via <code>return words;</code>.</p>

<p>Not only is this the only way you allow for return-value optimization, but moreover, the local variable will also bind to the move constructor of the returned object in the (unusual) case where the copy is not elided altogether. So it's a true triple-win scenario.</p>

12666372,"<p>I think this will do it for you:</p>

<pre><code>mapply(setdiff, head(dtl, -1), tail(dtl, -1), SIMPLIFY = FALSE)
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Edit</strong>: with your new expected output, I would still use <code>mapply</code> as above, but with one of the following two changes:</p>

<ol>
<li>replace <code>setdiff</code> with <code>function(x,y)setdiff(x$id, y$id)</code></li>
<li>replace <code>dtl</code> with <code>ids &lt;- lapply(dtl, ""["", ""id"")</code></li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Edit2:</strong>: you've changed your expected output again by adding a plain English description that does not match the code you had provided... I <em>think</em> you are now looking for this:</p>

<pre><code>mapply(function(x,y)y[setdiff(y$id, x$id), ],
       head(dtl, -1), tail(dtl, -1), SIMPLIFY = FALSE)
</code></pre>

12666382,"<p>Bluetooth LE would be the way you want to go here, because standard Bluetooth requires your device to be <a href=""https://developer.apple.com/programs/mfi/"" rel=""nofollow"">MFi</a>-compliant. Standard Wi-Fi could also work, if you're able to require the presence of the supporting network.</p>

<p>As of iOS 6.0, you can set up your iPhone as a Bluetooth LE peripheral, which would allow it to send notifications to your device, if it is configured in a central role. That would be a pretty power-efficient way of updating your device with new data.</p>

<p>However, there's one large hurdle to doing what you want here. iOS applications have no access to system-wide notifications, so you won't be able to listen for incoming emails or other notifications like that. You'll be able to send data to your device via Bluetooth LE, but you're not going to know when emails come in so that you could send that to your device.</p>

",1349052436,1,c++ arrays string character,Concatenating character arrays in c++,1662019
12666384,"<p>Please be more precise and concrete and ask one question at a time. You have better chance for getting an answer to all of the questions when asked separately. Now let me try covering some of your questions.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>1) Can I created a federated DB on an active Database or do I need to
  deploy federations ahead of time?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>You can certainly create a Federation(s) within an existing DB. There is no limitation to creating Federations in just a new/empty DB. However, creating a federation in an Active DB will do nothing for you. You have to realize that Federations are separate DBs. A Federation (or Federation member) knows nothing about the Federations Root DB (the DB where you created the federation). So you have to think on migrating schema/data from the Active DB (or the Federations Root) once you create your federation. </p>

<blockquote>
  <p>2) Do I need to make any changes to the SQL queries to comply with how
  I query federations, or I can continue to use my regular queries as I
  was working against one SQL Server Database?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Most probably YES. Windows Azure SQL Database Federations is a Scale-Out mechanism for the DB tier. This means, that like any Web Application needs a ""special"" design to work in a farm-like environment (i.e. scale-out environment like Windows Azure), a DataBase will also need a ""special"" design to work in a scale-out environment. There is no magic-wand with SQL Azure Federations that will make your code work. You have to design it to Work.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>3) When I split my database and after some time I see that one of the
  shards is very busy and almost full, how I tackle this problem using
  federations? - Do I need to split only that single federated table
  that is 90% full, or I need to recreate the splitting strategy by
  using a a less broader range. The problem is that one specific user
  can be very active, so what strategy I use to making sure that I won't
  need to re-create the federated strategy due to one very active
  federated table / user?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This is all about partitioning strategy. You have to very carefully design your federation key and how you partition your data across different shards. You can always SPLIT any federation, as long as you keep the Atomic Units in single shard.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>4) When I have different tables that I want to split with different
  primary keys, how the sharding will work then.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you want to split different tables on different keys, than you will have different federations, each one with its own federation key and own tables. </p>

<p>A good video worth watching if you are up for SQL Federations: <a href=""http://channel9.msdn.com/Events/TechEd/NorthAmerica/2012/DBI408"" rel=""nofollow"">http://channel9.msdn.com/Events/TechEd/NorthAmerica/2012/DBI408</a> </p>
",1349073052,12668445,True,"<p>I have a few questions regarding Microsoft SQL Azure Federations:</p>

<p>1) Can I created a federated DB on an active Database or do I need to deploy federations ahead of time?</p>

<p>2) Do I need to make any changes to the SQL queries to comply with how I query federations, or I can continue to use my regular queries as I was working against one SQL Server Database?</p>

<p>3) When I split my database and after some time I see that one of the shards is very busy and almost full, how I tackle this problem using federations? - Do I need to split only that single federated table that is 90% full, or I need to recreate the splitting strategy by using a a less broader range. The problem is that one specific user can be very active, so what strategy I use to making sure that I won't need to re-create the federated strategy due to one  very active federated table / user?</p>

12666388,"<p>Your <code>-=</code> operator should be changing the values of <code>numerator</code> and <code>denominator</code>, but it does not. Add code to set these values into <code>this</code>, instead of creating <code>result</code>:</p>

<pre><code>Rational&amp; Rational::operator-=(const Rational&amp; subtracted) {
    numerator = (*this).getNumerator()*subtracted.getDenominator() - (*this).getDenominator()*subtracted.getNumerator();
    denominator = (*this).getDenominator()*subtracted.getDenominator();
    return *this;
}
</code></pre>

    { }

    int getDenominator() const;
    Rational&amp; operator-=(const Rational&amp; bar);

private:
    int numerator, denominator;

rational.cc:
Rational&amp; Rational::operator-=(const Rational&amp; subtracted) {
    Rational result((*this).getNumerator()*subtracted.getDenominator() - (*this).getDenominator()*subtracted.getNumerator(), (*this).getDenominator()*subtracted.getDenominator());

",1349052676,3,java scala maven,Creating an executable with Scala/Maven,4249
12666402,"<p>SUGGESTION:</p>

<pre><code>    #include &lt;stdio.h&gt;
    #include &lt;string.h&gt;
    #include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;

    #define MAXLINE 80
    #define MAXRECORDS 10

    struct info{
      char name[100];
      char number[12];
      char address[100];
      char city[20];
      char state[2];
      int zip;
    };

    int 
    main(int argc, char *argv[])
    {
      FILE *fp = NULL;
      int nrecs = 0;
      char line[MAXLINE];
      struct info input_records[MAXRECORDS];

      /* Check for cmd arguments */
      if (argc != 2) {
        printf (""ERROR: you must specify file name!\n"");
        return 1;

      /* Open file */
      fp = fopen(argv[1], ""r"");
      if (!fp) {
        perror (""File open error!\n"");
        return 1;
      }

      /* Read file and parse text into your data records */
      while (!feof (fp)) {
        if (fgets(line, sizeof (line), fp) {
          printf(""next line= %s\n"", line);
          parse(line, input_records[nrecs]);
          nrecs++;
        }
      }

      /* Done */
      fclose (fp);
      return 0;
    }    
  fclose(fileStream);

}
</code></pre>

<p>Key points:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>Note use of ""argc/argv[]"" to read input filename from command line</p></li>
<li><p>line, nrecs, etc are all local variables (not globals)</p></li>
<li><p>Check for error conditions like ""filename not given"" or ""unable to open file""</p></li>
<li><p>Read your data in a loop, until end of input file</p></li>
<li><p>Parse the data you've read from the text file into an array of binary records (TBD)</p></li>
</ul>
",1349053580,12666475,True,"<p>I am very new to C and I am having trouble with the most fundamental ideas in C.  We are starting structures and basically the assignment we are working on is to read a delimited file and save the contents into a structure.  The first line of the file has the number of entries and alls that I am trying to do at the moment is get the program to read and save that number and print it out.  Please do not assume I know anything about C I really am very new to this.</p>

<p>This code is giving me a segmentation fault</p>

<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;
#include &lt;string.h&gt;
#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;


struct info{
  char name[100];
  char number[12];
  char address[100];
  char city[20];
  char state[2];
  int zip;
};

int strucCount;
char fileText[1];

int main(char *file)
{
  FILE *fileStream = fopen(file, ""r"");
  fgets(fileText, 1, fileStream);

  printf(""\n%s\n"",fileText);

  fclose(fileStream);

}
</code></pre>

<p>Here is the sample file</p>

<pre><code>4
mike|203-376-5555|7 Melba Ave|Milford|CT|06461
jake|203-555-5555|8 Melba Ave|Hartford|CT|65484
snake|203-555-5555|9 Melba Ave|Stamford|CT|06465
liquid|203-777-5555|2 Melba Ave|Barftown|CT|32154
</code></pre>

12666446,"<p>Assuming what you're aiming for is just to have the label snap to the bottom of the image, programmatic is your best approach - I don't think there's a way to do it in Interface Builder. If you set up the image and label as IBOutlets named <code>image</code> and <code>label</code> respectively, code like the following should give you what you're aiming for:</p>

<pre><code>CGRect label_frame = CGRectMake(label.frame.origin.x, image.frame.origin.y + image.frame.size.height, label.frame.size.width, label.frame.size.height);
label.frame = label_frame;
</code></pre>

<p>Call this whenever the image is changed and the text should be positioned below it, top edge of the label aligned with the bottom of the image. Remember you may need to alter the scroll view's <code>contentSize</code> to match if the image/text becomes larger.</p>

<p>Controller code (postTextLabel and postPicture are connected IBOutlets)</p>

<pre><code>#import ""DetailViewController.h""

@interface DetailViewController ()

- (void)configureView;

@end

@implementation DetailViewController;

@synthesize scroller;

- (void)viewDidLoad
{
    [super viewDidLoad];
    [self configureView];

        CGRect label_frame = CGRectMake(postTextLabel.frame.origin.x,
                                        postPicture.frame.origin.y + postPicture.frame.size.height,
                                        postTextLabel.frame.size.width,
                                        postTextLabel.frame.size.height);

        postTextLabel.frame = label_frame;

}

- (void)configureView
{
    if (self.detailItem) {
        NSDictionary *post           = self.detailItem;
        NSString     *postText       = [post objectForKey:@""post_text""];
        NSString     *postAuthorName = [post objectForKey:@""post_author_name""];

        postTextLabel.numberOfLines = 0;
        postTextLabel.text       = postText;
        postAuthorNameLabel.text = postAuthorName;

        dispatch_async(dispatch_get_global_queue(DISPATCH_QUEUE_PRIORITY_DEFAULT, 0), ^{
            NSString *pictureUrl = [post objectForKey:@""post_picture""];
            NSData   *data       = [NSData dataWithContentsOfURL:[NSURL URLWithString:pictureUrl]];

            dispatch_async(dispatch_get_main_queue(), ^{
                postPicture.image = [UIImage imageWithData:data];
            });
        });
    }
}

- (void)didReceiveMemoryWarning
{
    [super didReceiveMemoryWarning];
}
@end
</code></pre>

12666447,"<p>Opera's ECMAScript engine seems to be doing some over-eager optimisation here, where ""(0||eval)"" is simplified to just ""eval"" before compilation. In this case, this optimisation introduces a bug because it changes the behaviour of the code.</p>

<p>(Internally at Opera we track this issue as CORE-47727)</p>
",1349788334,12800845,True,"<p>In strict mode, indirect calls to <code>eval</code> should have <code>this</code> bound to the global object in eval code.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>10.4.2: In Edition 5, indirect calls to the eval function use the global environment as both the variable environment and lexical environment for the eval code. In Edition 3, the variable and lexical environments of the caller of an indirect eval was used as the environments for the eval code.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>However, in Opera, this expression results in <code>undefined</code>:</p>

<pre><code>(function(){'use strict'; return (0 || eval)('this'); }())
</code></pre>

<p>Chrome and Firefox work as expected.</p>

<p>I found this here: <a href=""http://kangax.github.com/jstests/indirect-eval-testsuite/"" rel=""nofollow"">http://kangax.github.com/jstests/indirect-eval-testsuite/</a></p>

<p>Is this a browser bug? If so, is it being tracked yet?</p>

<p>See also <a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12666272/why-do-some-forms-of-indirect-eval-fail-in-opera-and-safari"">Why do some forms of indirect eval fail in Opera and Safari?</a></p>

12666453,"<p>""The diamond problem"" isn't a problem, it's a symptom of not understanding the distinction between virtual and non-virtual inheritance. In the code above, the class <code>Output</code> has two base classes of type <code>Graphics</code>, one from <code>Output</code> and one from <code>IosGraphics</code>. It also has two base classes of type <code>Text</code>, one from <code>Output</code> and one from <code>IosText</code>. So <code>output-&gt;Print(""Hello, World!)</code> calls the implementation of <code>Print()</code> in its base, that is, it calls <code>Text::Print()</code>. It doesn't know anything about <code>IosGraphics::Print()</code>.</p>

<p>If you change <code>IosGraphics</code> to have <code>Graphics</code> as a <strong>virtual</strong> base, and change <code>IosText</code> to have <code>Text</code> as a <strong>virtual</strong> base, and change <code>Output</code> to have <code>Graphics</code> and <code>Text</code> as <strong>virtual</strong> bases, then things will do what you want because of the <strong>Dominance</strong> rule. <code>Output</code> doesn't override <code>Rect()</code> but <code>IosGraphics</code> does, so virtual calls to <code>Output-&gt;Rect()</code> go to <code>IosGraphics::Rect()</code>, and similarly for <code>Text::Print()</code>.</p>

<p>I know, that sounds like magic. The rule is a bit weird, but it works. Try it.</p>
",1349054325,12666534,True,"<p>I'm trying to come up with an abstraction for a game framework and one approach is to create,  for example, a graphics and audio class, these are the interfaces used by your games, and you derive specific implementations for your target platforms ( desktop/mobile/console ).</p>

<p>I have some example code of the idea here:</p>

<pre><code>#include &lt;iostream&gt;
#include &lt;string&gt;

using namespace std;

struct Graphics
{
    virtual ~Graphics() {}
    virtual void Rect() {}
};

struct Text
{
    virtual ~Text() {}
    virtual void Print(string s) {}
};

struct IosGraphics : public Graphics
{
    void Rect() { cout &lt;&lt; ""[]""; }
};

struct IosText : public Text
{
    void Print(string s) { cout &lt;&lt; s &lt;&lt; endl; }
};

struct Output : public Graphics, public Text
{
};

struct IosOutput : public Output, public IosGraphics, public IosText
{
};

int main() 
{ 
    Output * output = new IosOutput();
    output-&gt;Rect(); // this calling Graphics::Rect not IosGraphics::Rect
    output-&gt;Print(""Hello World!""); // this calling Text::Print not IosText::Print
    cin.get();
}
</code></pre>

<p>The problem is that output is using the Text::Print instead of IosText::Print, I wonder if this is related to the diamond problem and I might have to use virtual inheritance or something. Any help is greatly appreciated.</p>
",1349053292,2,c++ oop,Trouble with multiple inheritance,1593860

",1349054553,12666556,True,"<p>I have a collection with predefined questions and a user whom should answer all these questions. So the view should be something like:</p>

    %table.table
      - @user.answers.each do |answer|
        = f.fields_for :answers, answer do |a|
          %tr
            %td= answer.question.name
            %td=a.number_field :result
</code></pre>

<p>In this case there won't be any answers so nothing will show. Even if there would be an answer I must to show all the questions to the user.
