",1349057462,2,heroku,Heroku bash - where's vi?,77409
12666800,"<p>I think the problem is that, in step 3, you try to set the <code>className</code> of <code>accordionParagraphs</code>, which is actually an array rather than an element.</p>

<p>Try replacing it with something like this:</p>

<pre><code>accordionHeadings[i].onclick = function accordion() {

    // 'this' refers to the element that was clicked
    // 'nextElementSibling' gets the element directly after it
    var accParagraph = this.nextElementSibling;

    // now you have the right element, you can change its class
    if (accParagraph.className == 'hidecontent') {
        accParagraph.className = 'showcontent';
    } else {
        accParagraph.className = 'hidecontent';
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Edit:</p>

<p>You could also do it like this:</p>

<pre><code>// 'this' refers to the element that was clicked (heading)
// 'parentNode' gets its parent
// 'getElementsByTagName('p')[0]' selects the first &lt;p&gt; element
var accParagraph = this.parentNode.getElementsByTagName('p')[0]; 
</code></pre>

            &lt;li&gt;Create a second class with a single declaration: &lt;em&gt;display:block;&lt;/em&gt; Name the class &lt;strong&gt;.showContent&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;
            &lt;li&gt;Create two more CSS rules. One should remove the bottom margin from all H2s. The other should remove the top margin from all paragraphs.&lt;/li&gt;
          &lt;/ul&gt;

          &lt;ul&gt;
          &lt;li&gt;Create exactly two functions. One called &lt;strong&gt;preparePage()&lt;/strong&gt; that automatically applies the .hideContent style to all paragraphs within the accordion div and then makes the desired H2s call the second function when clicked. The second function,&lt;strong&gt;accordion()&lt;/strong&gt;, performs the class switching.&lt;/li&gt;
          &lt;li&gt;Make preparePage() run when the page loads.&lt;/li&gt;
          &lt;li&gt;When an H2 inside the ""accordion"" div is clicked, the associated paragraph should change class so that it appears. If the paragraph is already visible, then it should disappear when its H2 is clicked.&lt;/li&gt;
          &lt;li&gt;No inline JavaScript should appear in the HTML. Only a SCRIPT tag should be present in the HTML. No other JavaScript should be in the HTML anywhere.&lt;/li&gt;
          &lt;li&gt;Study the HTML first so you know the structure! Similar to backing up out of folders (like you did in NOS-110 using subdirectory markers) you will have to &amp;quot;back up&amp;quot; out of the H2 to get its parentNode. Then you can use that parentNode to descend back down to the child paragraph.&lt;/li&gt;
          &lt;/ul&gt;
          &lt;/li&gt;

</code></pre>

<p><strong>CSS</strong></p>

<pre><code>/* create a class that hides the text */
.hidecontent {
display: none;
}

/* create a class that shows the text */
.showcontent {
display: block;
}

/* h2 rules */
h2 {
margin-bottom: 0;
}

/* paragraph rules */
p {
margin-top: 0;
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>JavaScript</strong></p>

<pre><code>/* once the page finishes loading, run the preparePage function */
window.onload = function preparePage() {

/* Step 1: get the necessary elements needed from the accordion div section of the HTML */
    var accodion = document.getElementById('accordion');                    
var accordionHeadings = accordion.getElementsByTagName('h2');               
var accordionParagraphs = accordion.getElementsByTagName('p');                      

/* Step 2: use a for loop to set the class of the accordionParagraphs to 'hidecontent' */
for (var i = 0; i &lt; accordionParagraphs.length; i++) {                  
    accordionParagraphs[i].className = 'hidecontent';               
}

/* Step 3: use a for loop to get to the headings
 * when a heading is clicked,
 * run the accordion funtion
 */
    for(var i = 0; i &lt; accordionHeadings.length; i++) {
        accordionHeadings[i].onclick = function accordion() {
            if(accordionParagraphs.className == 'hidecontent') {
                accordionParagraphs.className = 'showcontent';
            } else {
                accordionParagraphs.className = 'hidecontent';
            }
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

12666814,"<p>You're only recording half the traffic, i.e. in one direction. The ACKs are for the part you aren't recording. Try a filter that includes destination port 80.</p>
",1349062614,12667241,True,"<p>I am writing an app where I am printing TCP sequence and ack numbers.
I ran tcpdump on the same box and the numbers do not match. Here is my
code, all headers and structures are from <a href=""http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=1&amp;cad=rja&amp;ved=0CCIQFjAA&amp;url=http://www.tcpdump.org/sniffex.c&amp;ei=3_toUKOUK4XA9gTQ4oHoBA&amp;usg=AFQjCNG06vPZLcb_gnMas5sM1m7uu5K53A&amp;sig2=pdfscbubzfUEDSZdGEuwcQ"" rel=""nofollow"">sniffex.c</a></p>

<pre><code>void
got_packet(u_char *args, const struct pcap_pkthdr *header, const u_char *packet)
{

    static int count = 1;                   /* packet counter */

    /* declare pointers to packet headers */
    const struct sniff_ethernet *ethernet;  /* The ethernet header [1] */
    const struct sniff_ip *ip;              /* The IP header */
    const struct sniff_tcp *tcp;            /* The TCP header */

    int size_ip;
    int size_tcp;
    int size_payload;

    count++;

    /* define ethernet header */
    ethernet = (struct sniff_ethernet*)(packet);

    /* define/compute ip header offset */
    ip = (struct sniff_ip*)(packet + SIZE_ETHERNET);
    size_ip = IP_HL(ip)*4;
    if (size_ip &lt; 20) {
        printf(""   * Invalid IP header length: %u bytes\n"", size_ip);
        return;
    }

    /* determine protocol */
    switch(ip-&gt;ip_p) {
        case IPPROTO_TCP:
            printf(""   Protocol: TCP\n"");
            break;
        case IPPROTO_UDP:
            printf(""   Protocol: UDP\n"");
            return;
        case IPPROTO_ICMP:
            printf(""   Protocol: ICMP\n"");
            return;
        case IPPROTO_IP:
            printf(""   Protocol: IP\n"");
            return;
        default:
            printf(""   Protocol: unknown\n"");
            return;
    }


    /* define/compute tcp header offset */
    tcp = (struct sniff_tcp*)(packet + SIZE_ETHERNET + size_ip);
    size_tcp = TH_OFF(tcp)*4;
    if (size_tcp &lt; 20) {
        printf(""   * Invalid TCP header length: %u bytes\n"", size_tcp);
        return;
    }

    std::cout &lt;&lt; ""Packet# "" &lt;&lt; count &lt;&lt; "" S "" &lt;&lt; tcp-&gt;th_seq &lt;&lt; "" A ""
&lt;&lt; tcp-&gt;th_ack &lt;&lt; ""\n"";

}
</code></pre>

<p>And this prints:</p>

<pre><code>Packet# 2 S 1063936835 A 1371648504
Packet# 3 S 1080714051 A 1975693816
Packet# 4 S 1080714051 A 1975693816
Packet# 5 S 141321027 A 2730734072
Packet# 6 S 2960220995 A 2730734072
Packet# 7 S 1484219203 A 2730734072
Packet# 8 S 8217411 A 2730734072
Packet# 9 S 2827117379 A 2730734072
Packet# 10 S 1351115587 A 2730734072
</code></pre>

<p>I ran tcpdump to record a pcap file as:</p>

<pre><code># sudo tcpdump -n -i eth0 -S -n -w cache.cap 'tcp and src port 80'
</code></pre>

<p>And then inspected it with</p>

<pre><code># sudo tcpdump -S -ttttnnr cache.cap
reading from file cache.cap, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet)

12666822,"<p>Every SQL database uses its own implementation of the language that varies slightly. While basic queries are almost universal, there notable are nuances between MySQL, PostgreSQL, Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle Database, etc.</p>

<p>What's particularly notable about SQLite is that unlike all the others mentioned above, this database software doesn't come with a daemon that queries are passed through. This means that if multiple processes are using the database at once, they will be directly altering the data through the SQLite library and making the read / write data calls to the OS themselves. It also means that the locking mechanisms don't deal with contention very well.</p>

<p>This isn't a problem for most applications that where one would think of using SQLite -- the small overhead benefits and easy data retrieval are worth it. However, if you'll be accessing your database with more than one process or don't consider mapping all your requests through one thread, it could be slightly troublesome.</p>
",1349058168,12666856,True,"<p>I know SQLite Data Base is  used in  mobile devices (Andrdoid , Iphone ) and it is light takes only kb space. Is there any limitation in SQLite. I want to know how they are different.</p>
",1349057727,3,android sql database sqlite,What is difference between SQLite and SQL,90322
12666825,"<p>There is certainly no way that that function will ever return a null pointer, so there's no point checking for that. It might make more sense to return a reference, to make it clear that it won't be null.</p>

<p>However, there's no guarantee that the function will always return a pointer to a valid object. If it's called from the destructor of a static object, then <code>obj</code> might already have been destroyed. This is one reason why globally accessible objects are a very bad idea, whether or not you wrap them up in the Singleton anti-pattern like this.</p>

12666830,"<p>Use a regex with the pattern</p>

<pre><code>.split(""[^0-9][.,]|[.,][^0-9]|\\s+|(?![.,])\\p{Punct}"")
</code></pre>

<p>That will split anything that doesn't have a number on both sides of a period or comma, or any other punctuation that isn't a period or comma. The 3rd section between pipes covers any spaces. That last part is based on a negative lookahead which is discussed in <a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/a/8200935/90322"">this answer</a> to prevent the already matched commas and periods that we kept safe from splitting numbers from being matched here.</p>

12666838,"<p>For a javascript-based game, I'd recommend hard-coding an array client-side and storing only IMPORTANT coordinates in there to reduce the size of the array so you don't have to check it as often. Then switch to a bitmap/bitboard representation much like how most modern chess engines function today. Then have a bitmap for each possible block type e.g. wall, empty, stairs, etc. The concept of a bitmap is to map the coordinates of the pieces of interest. Pieces on the map are given a boolean true value while unmapped coordinates will have a boolean false value. Then repeat this process for each block type.</p>

<p>e.g.</p>

<pre><code>walls:[[3,-7],[-8,9],[30,67],[31,67],[32,68]]
ustairs:[[4,6],[7,8],[8,9]]
dstairs:[[7,6],[-2,-4],[-7,-9]]
</code></pre>

<p>Even if you decide not to switch to a bitmap/bitboard representation, at least have mercy on your database backend if you wind-up storing all the coordinates there.</p>

<p>You could use PHP's <code>imagecolorat()</code> function to populate your database but I would vote against using this function at runtime everytime you need to check a coordinate.
This function works well with non-indexed images such as PNGs.</p>

<p>But if you open up an indexed image in PHP such as a GIF, then you will have to look up the color for the index used in the image before getting its color value. Thus you would use <code>imagecolorsforindex()</code>. Edit: Sorry I mean <code>imagecolorexact()</code></p>

12666844,"<p>go for list and remove color once used:</p>

<pre><code>private static ArrayList&lt;String&gt; arrayList = new ArrayList&lt;String&gt;();
private static Random random = new Random();
public static void fillList(){
    arrayList.add(""Red"");
    arrayList.add(""Blue"");
    arrayList.add(""Green"");
    arrayList.add(""Orange"");
}
public static String getNextRandomColor(){
    if(arrayList.isEmpty()){
        fillList();
    }
    return arrayList.remove(random.nextInt(arrayList.size()));
}
</code></pre>

12666845,"<p>It's better to keep browser sniffing client-side. But if you really have to do it in a Rails template, you can make a helper:</p>

<p><strong>_social.html.erb</strong></p>

<pre><code>&lt;% if ie7?(request) %&gt;
  do ie7 stuff
&lt;% else %&gt;
  do other stuff
&lt;% end %&gt;
</code></pre>

<p><strong>application_helper.rb</strong></p>

<pre><code>def ie7?(request)
  if request.user_agent
    !!request.user_agent.match(/msie 7.0/i)
  end
end
</code></pre>

12666869,"<p>First, you need to pass the list by reference; your code is working on a copy, so changes it makes won't affect the caller's list:</p>

<pre><code>void FileReader::DeleteProcess(int id, list&lt;Process&gt; &amp; listToDeleteFrom)
                                                     ^
</code></pre>

<p>Second, erasing a list element invalidates any iterator that refers to that element, so attempting to carry on iterating afterwards will cause undefined behaviour. If there will only be one element to remove, then return from the function straight after the call to <code>erase</code>; otherwise, the loop needs to be structured something like:</p>

<pre><code>for (auto it = list.begin(); it != list.end(); /* don't increment here */) {
    if (it-&gt;ID == id) {
        it = list.erase(it);
    } else {
        ++it;
    }
}
</code></pre>

<pre><code>&lt;?xml version=""1.0"" encoding=""UTF-8""?&gt;
&lt;configuration&gt;
    &lt;system.webServer&gt;
        &lt;directoryBrowse enabled=""false"" /&gt;
        &lt;defaultDocument&gt;
            &lt;files&gt;
                &lt;clear /&gt;
                &lt;add value=""index.php"" /&gt;
                &lt;add value=""Default.htm"" /&gt;
                &lt;add value=""Default.asp"" /&gt;
                &lt;add value=""index.htm"" /&gt;
                &lt;add value=""Default.aspx"" /&gt;
            &lt;/files&gt;

                &lt;rule name=""Add WWW prefix"" &gt;
                  &lt;match url=""(.*)"" ignoreCase=""true"" /&gt;
                    &lt;conditions&gt;
                      &lt;add input=""{HTTP_HOST}"" pattern=""^example\.com"" /&gt;
                    &lt;/conditions&gt;
                  &lt;action type=""Redirect"" url=""http://www.example.com/{R:1}""
                    redirectType=""Permanent"" /&gt;
                &lt;/rule&gt; 

                &lt;rule name=""ModX IIS7 Rule 1"" stopProcessing=""true""&gt;
                    &lt;match url="".*"" ignoreCase=""false"" /&gt;
                    &lt;conditions logicalGrouping=""MatchAll""&gt;
                        &lt;add input=""{HTTP_USER_AGENT}"" pattern=""^.*internal\ dummy\ connection.*$"" /&gt;
                    &lt;/conditions&gt;
                    &lt;action type=""CustomResponse"" statusCode=""403"" statusReason=""Forbidden"" statusDescription=""Forbidden"" /&gt;
                &lt;/rule&gt;
                &lt;rule name=""ModX IIS7 Rule 2"" stopProcessing=""true""&gt;
                    &lt;match url=""^(manager|assets)"" ignoreCase=""false"" /&gt;
                    &lt;action type=""None"" /&gt;

                    &lt;match url=""^(.*)$"" ignoreCase=""false"" /&gt;
                    &lt;conditions logicalGrouping=""MatchAll""&gt;
                        &lt;add input=""{REQUEST_FILENAME}"" matchType=""IsFile"" negate=""true"" pattern="""" ignoreCase=""false"" /&gt;

12666877,"<p>As long as you are never assigning the model or view variables to anything that will stick around. Be wary of closures around the variables, don't attach the variables as attributes of any other object, don't attach the view or model to any events from any other objects. Then yes, this will clean itself up.</p>

<p>But those are some pretty strict rules to abide by and don't play well with most apps. You should be handling the removal of event handlers explicitly, and deleting any attribute on any object you had created.</p>

<p>I have a few articles related to this (seems likely you've read at least one of them, already):</p>

<p>The classic Zombies post: <a href=""http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2011/09/15/zombies-run-managing-page-transitions-in-backbone-apps/"" rel=""nofollow"">http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2011/09/15/zombies-run-managing-page-transitions-in-backbone-apps/</a></p>

<p>an implementation of the zombie's cleanup code, plus more, as an object on it's own: <a href=""http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2011/12/12/composite-js-apps-regions-and-region-managers/"" rel=""nofollow"">http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2011/12/12/composite-js-apps-regions-and-region-managers/</a> </p>

<p>Memory management in JavaScript and Backbone: <a href=""http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2012/03/19/backbone-js-and-javascript-garbage-collection/"" rel=""nofollow"">http://lostechies.com/derickbailey/2012/03/19/backbone-js-and-javascript-garbage-collection/</a></p>

12666879,"<p>Logical Error: You're slicing from index 1 instead of 0 in <code>list.(word)(1:len(word)/2:)</code></p>

<p>Syntax Errors: <code>list.(word)</code> is incorrect syntax, and list slicing uses [ ] not ( ). Simply use <code>word[start:stop]</code> to break it up</p>

<p>Use:</p>

<p><code>[word for word in lowers if word[:len(word)//2]==word[len(word)//2:]]</code></p>

<p>Edit: Thanks to Ignacio Vazquez-Abrams' comment - Use integer division ( // operator ) for Python 3 compatibility</p>

12666883,"<p>I'm not sure <em>exactly</em> what you want, but for the whole week, try something like:</p>

<pre><code>select av.*, ap.*,c.* from tbl_available av 
left join tbl_appointment ap on av.avHours = ap.appointmenttime 
and ap.calendarid = kalenderId 
and ap.appointmentdate BETWEEN dag AND DATE_ADD(dag, INTERVAL 6 DAY)
and (av.avDays = DayOfweek(ap.appointmentdate) OR ap.appointmentdate IS NULL)
left join tbl_client c on ap.clientid = c.clientid
where av.avCalendarId = KalenderId 
order by avHours;
</code></pre>

<p>I'm using <code>BETWEEN</code> to specify the date range for <code>ap.appointmentdate</code>. The <code>av.avDays</code> is changed to either correlate to <code>ap.appointmentdate</code> or also show rows with no appointment (assumed this behavior because you have a <code>LEFT JOIN</code> on <code>tbl_appointment</code>). I have left off <code>DayOfweek(dag) ...</code> because you are looking at a whole week so this is redundant.</p>

12666894,"<p>If you have access to the class definitions, you could create a special <code>friend</code> function that can be used to access the private members of each class and copy the private members from one class to another.</p>

<p>For instance:</p>

<pre><code>class B; //forward declaration

class A
{
    private:
        //... private data members

    public:
        //... methods, etc.

        friend void copy(const A&amp;, B&amp;);
};

class B
{
    private:
        //... private data members

    public:
        //... methods, etc.

        friend void copy(const A&amp;, B&amp;);
};

void copy(const A&amp; rhs, B&amp; lhs)
{
    //... copy the private elements out of class A into class B
}
</code></pre>

<p>Of course then again, if you had access to the class definitions, there's a number of things you could do including adding a simple method to one of the classes, declaring one class the <code>friend</code> of the other, etc.  If someone else created the code and declared those data-members private, then either they missed a use-case or you shouldn't be touching that data ...</p>

    public void preStart()
    {

        /* Get reference to Master Node*/
         masterActor = getContext().
            actorFor(""akka://MasterNode@127.0.0.1:9002/user/masterNode/masterActor"");
    }

    @Override
    public void onReceive(Object message) throws Exception {
        System.out.println("" Future called  "");

        Future&lt;Object&gt; future = Patterns.ask(masterActor , message, timeout);

            String result = (String) Await.result(future, timeout.duration());

    }

            .getConfig(""masterNode""));
        ActorRef masterActor = system.actorOf(new Props(MasterActor.class),""masterActor"");
        System.out.println("" Master Node is called "");
      }  
      public void startup() {

      }      
          public void shutdown() {
            system.shutdown();
          }
}

    public void onReceive(Object message) throws Exception {
        System.out.print("" this is from me to you  ""+message.toString());

         if (message instanceof String) {
                // Get reference to the message sender and reply back
                getSender().tell(message + "" got something"");
                System.out.print("" this is from me to you  ""+message.toString());
    }
  }  
}

",1349058740,0,java playframework playframework-2.0 akka future,Play 2.0.2 with Akka remote system,227803
12666915,"<p><code>string.SubString</code>'s second argument is the length of the substring.</p>

<p>In your example, you're saying <code>grab the string starting at &lt;start&gt; and is &lt;end&gt; characters long</code>. If <code>start</code> is 2 and the length of the string is 11, then <code>end</code> would be 10.. which if added together makes 12 (10+2=12.. while the length of the string is 11).</p>

<p>You need this:</p>

<pre><code>return text.Substring(start, end - start);
</code></pre>

<p>..and this:</p>

<pre><code>while (end &lt; text.Length)
</code></pre>
",1349059367,12666951,True,"<p>I'm trying to get the string after the given word. Below is the code.</p>

<pre><code>private static string GetStringAfterWord(string text, int position)
    {
        if (text.Length - 1 &lt; position || text[position] == ' ') return null;

        int start = position;
        int end = position;

        while (end &lt; text.Length - 1 )   
        end++;

        return text.Substring(start, end);

    }
</code></pre>

<p>This code always give me this error:  System.ArgumentOutOfRangeException: Index and length must refer to a location within the string.</p>

<p>Isn't the string.Length return the number of total characters and why is always out of range. Am i doing this wrong?</p>
",1349058940,1,c# asp.net-mvc string substring,Why is string.Length not working on text.Substring?,1517578
12666916,"<p>C11 clarifies that this is undefined.</p>

<p>You can find the final draft of C11 <a href=""http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n1570.pdf"" rel=""nofollow"">here</a>.  The second sentence you quoted now refers to footnote 111:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>An assignment operator stores a value in the object designated by the left operand. An assignment expression has the value of the left operand after the assignment,<sup>111)</sup> but is not an lvalue.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Footnote 111 says this:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>111) The implementation is permitted to read the object to determine the value but is not required to, even when the object has volatile-qualified type.</p>
</blockquote>
",1349067377,12667704,True,"<p>I seem to have a reasonable understanding of <code>volatiles</code> in general, but there's one seemingly obscure case, in which I'm not sure how things are supposed to work per the standard. I've read the relevant parts of C99 and a dozen or more related posts on SO, but can't find the logic in this case or a place where this case is explained.</p>

<p>Suppose we have this piece of code:</p>

<pre><code>  int a, c;
  volatile int b;
  a = b = 1;
  c = b += 1; /* or equivalently c = ++b; */
</code></pre>

<p>Should <code>a</code> be evaluated like this:</p>

<pre><code>  b = 1;
  a = b; // volatile is read
</code></pre>

<p>or like this:</p>

<pre><code>  b = 1;
  a = 1; // volatile isn't read
</code></pre>

<p>?</p>

<p>Similarly, should <code>c</code> be evaluated like this:</p>

<pre><code>  int tmp = b;
  tmp++;
  b = tmp;
  c = b; // volatile is read
</code></pre>

<p>or like this:</p>

<pre><code>  int tmp = b;
  tmp++;
  b = tmp;
  c = tmp; // volatile isn't read
</code></pre>

<p>?</p>

<p>In simple cases like <code>a = b; c = b;</code> things are clear. But how about the ones above?</p>

<p>Basically, the question is, what exactly does ""expression has the value of the left operand after the assignment"" mean in 6.5.16c3 of C99 when the object is volatile?:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>An assignment operator stores a value in the object designated by the
      left operand. An assignment <strong><em>expression has the value of the left operand
      after the assignment</em></strong>, but is not an lvalue.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Does it imply an extra read of the volatile to produce the value of the assignment expression?</p>

<p><strong>UPDATE</strong>:</p>

<p>So, here's the dilemma.</p>

<p>If ""the value of the object after the assignment"" is not obtained from the extra read of the volatile object, then the compiler makes the assumption that the volatile object <code>b</code>:</p>

<ul>
<li>is capable of holding an arbitrary <code>int</code> value that gets written into it, which it may not be (say, bit 0 is hardwired to 0, which is not an unusual thing with hardware registers, for which we are supposed to use volatiles)</li>
<li>cannot change between the point when the assigning write has occurred and the point when the expression value is obtained (and again it can be a problem with hardware registers)</li>
</ul>

<p>And because of all that, the expression value, if not obtained from the extra read of the volatile object, does not yield the value of the volatile object, which the standard claims should be the case.</p>

<p>Both of these assumptions don't seem to fit well with the nature of volatile objects.</p>

<p>If, OTOH, ""the value of the object after the assignment"" is obtained from the extra implied read of said volatile object, then the side effects of evaluating assignment expressions with volatile left operands depend on whether the expression value is used or not or are completely arbitrary, which would be an odd, unexpected and poorly documented behavior.</p>
",1349058948,2,c volatile,assignment expressions and volatile,77567
12666919,"<p>You do this:</p>

<pre><code>NSManagedObjectContext *context = [self managedObjectContext];
</code></pre>

<p>But then you access this:</p>

<pre><code>self.managedObjectContext
</code></pre>

<p>Assuming your <code>NSLog(@""%@"", context);</code> shows a valid NSManagedObjectContext, then I would do this:</p>

<pre><code>NSEntityDescription *entity = [NSEntityDescription entityForName:@""Man"" inManagedObjectContext:context];
</code></pre>

<p>Or, change your original declaration to:</p>

<pre><code>self.managedObjectContext = [self managedObjectContext];
</code></pre>

12666922,"<p>Yes, they both return the same exception (possibly because of timeout internally using a token too) but it can be easily figured out by doing this:</p>

<pre><code>   catch (OperationCanceledException ex)
            {
                if (token.IsCancellationRequested)
                {
                    return -1;
                }

                return -2;
            }
</code></pre>

<p>so basically if you hit the exception but your token is not cancelled, well it was a regular http timeout</p>
",1362103389,15149214,False,"<p><code>HttpClient</code> has a builtin timeout feature (despite being all asynchronous, i.e. timeouts could be considered orthogonal to the http request functionality and thus be handled by generic asynchronous utilities, but that aside) and when the timeout kicks in, it'll throw a <code>TaskCanceledException</code> (wrapped in an <code>AggregateException</code>).</p>

<p>The TCE contains a <code>CancellationToken</code> that equals <code>CancellationToken.None</code>.</p>

<p>Now if I provide <code>HttpClient</code> with a <code>CancellationToken</code> of my own and use that to cancel the operation before it finishes (or times out), I get the exact same <code>TaskCanceledException</code>, again with a <code>CancellationToken.None</code>.</p>

<p>Is there still a way, <strong>by looking only at the exception thrown</strong>, to figure out whether a timeout canceled the request, without having to make my own <code>CancellationToken</code> accessible to the code that checks the exception?</p>

<p>P.S. Could this be a bug and <code>CancellationToken</code> got somehow wrongly fixed to <code>CancellationToken.None</code>? In the <em>cancelled using custom CancellationToken</em> case, I'd expect <code>TaskCanceledException.CancellationToken</code> to equal that custom token.</p>

<p><strong>Edit</strong> 
To make the problem a bit more clear, with access to the original <code>CancellationTokenSource</code>, it is easy to distinguish timeout and user cancellation:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>origCancellationTokenSource.IsCancellationRequested == <strong>true</strong></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Getting the <code>CancellationToken</code> from the exception though gives the wrong answer:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>((TaskCanceledException) e.InnerException).CancellationToken.IsCancellationRequested == <strong>false</strong></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Here <strong>a minimal example</strong>, due to popular demand:</p>

<pre><code>public void foo()
{
    makeRequest().ContinueWith(task =&gt;
    {
        try
        {
            var result = task.Result;
            // do something with the result;
        }
        catch (Exception e)
        {
            TaskCanceledException innerException = e.InnerException as TaskCanceledException;
            bool timedOut = innerException != null &amp;&amp; innerException.CancellationToken.IsCancellationRequested == false;

            // Unfortunately, the above .IsCancellationRequested
            // is always false, no matter if the request was
            // cancelled using CancellationTaskSource.Cancel()
            // or if it timed out
        }
    });
}

public Task&lt;HttpResponseMessage&gt; makeRequest()
{
    var cts = new CancellationTokenSource();
    HttpClient client = new HttpClient() { Timeout = TimeSpan.FromSeconds(10) };
    HttpRequestMessage httpRequestMessage = new HttpRequestMessage(HttpMethod.Get, ""url"");

    passCancellationTokenToOtherPartOfTheCode(cts);
    return client.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage, cts.Token);
}
</code></pre>

12666930,"<p>There is no guarantee that you'll get a useful error message if you don't handle an exception; the only guarantee is that the program will be terminated by calling <code>std::terminate</code>.</p>

<p>It seems that your implementation is able to identify that the unhandled exception was derived from <code>std::exception</code>, and use that knowledge to call its override of <code>what()</code> to generate an error message. It would know nothing about non-standard exception types, and it shouldn't randomly call functions just because they happen to have the same name as a function in a completely unrelated class.</p>

<p>If you want to print something useful when an arbitrary type is thrown, you'll need a handler to catch that type and do the right thing with it. But I would definitely advise you to only throw types derived from <code>std::exception</code> unless you've got a very good reason to throw something else.</p>

    ss &lt;&lt; ""Parse error at position "" &lt;&lt; position &lt;&lt; "": "" &lt;&lt; msg;

12666934,"<p>In practice, I would lean towards having param tags only list what you <em>want</em> passed in.  However, for return tags, you really do need to list every type that could possibly be returned.  Here's why I differ on the two.</p>

<p>Since PHP is not strongly typed, even when you say ""only pass in an int"", your method does still need to make sure it is not passed something unexpected.  Just because the method code tries to handle receiving other types, you don't want your docs to tell your users ""sure, you can pass me a NULL, and I'll do something with it for you"".  You want your docs to say ""give me an int, period"".</p>

<p>When considering return values, your users really really really need to know every potential return type that could come back from your method, because they really need to cover their bases in their code to handle all the types that your method might return.</p>

    $this-&gt;bar = $bar;
  }

  /**
   * @return int|null
   */
  public function getBar() {
    return $this-&gt;bar;
  }
}
</code></pre>

12666943,"<p>There are no such things as strings of <code>int</code>s or <code>double</code>s in C#<sup>*</sup>; the closest thing is a <code>List&lt;T&gt;</code>, but it does not support the typical string-specific operations, such as substrings, trimming, and so on.</p>

<p>You can do most of the things that you can with a string using .NET's LINQ. For example, <code>substring(1,5)</code> would be <code>list.Skip(1).Take(5).ToList()</code>.
<hr/>
<sup>*</sup> The same is true for C++: there is <code>basic_string</code> template that can be instantiated with other types, but <code>std::string</code> is an instance of a template class, not a template class itself.</p>

</code></pre>

</code></pre>

<p>With <code>ed</code>:</p>

<pre><code>echo 2,5p | ed -s FILE
</code></pre>

<p>With <code>ed</code> and two ranges :</p>

<pre><code>echo -e ""2,5p\n7,8p"" | ed -s FILE
</code></pre>

<p>Last but not least, a <code>sed</code> solution with two ranges (fastest solution, tested with <code>time</code>):</p>

<pre><code>sed -n '2,5p;7,8p' FILE
</code></pre>

12666957,"<p>Just because there exist seeders for a given torrent doesn't mean <em>your</em> client is aware of what they are seeding. You would need at least a magnet link, or a torrent file for each separate ""thing"".</p>

<p>So, ""caching"" content with torrent, ok, but as far as ""browsing"" is concerned, you need something else (eg: an index, that would list magnet/torrent files - and I doubt you would build that using lib/bittorrent...).</p>

<p>Secondly, your list of ""sources"" would be provided by a tracker in order to connect to your swarm, or at least a list of known peers (supernodes as you call them) if using DHT - yet again provided by something else that libtorrent.</p>

<p>Also, obviously (?) you can't ""update"" content with torrent - if something ""changes"", then it's a different torrent - so, short term, you would have a database with items that can't be modified... ""replicated"" over bittorrent, but indexed by some other technology.</p>

<p>I don't quite understand why you are looking at bittorrent to (re)implement a ""distributed database"", but this seems ill-formed to me (if only, because of the index, that wouldn't be distributed, pretty much defeating the purpose).</p>

<p>If your problem is reliability / scalability, why not consider any (existing) ""db"" engine that would natively do the job? (replica sets with mongo, or distributed filesystem on hadoop, or even good old-school handmade data replication between nodes, or even sql master slaves, or some cloud storage...).</p>

<p>If your problem is ""ownership"" over the database, yet again it's not about the content, it's about the index.
Now, I can imagine something where peers would exchange lists of items they own between them, allowing a given peer to get data from another given one, but this is quite far away from what I would call a ""database""...</p>

<p>I don't think you can let-go ""ownership"" (at least over the index) without letting go the concept of ""database""... (assuming I understood well what you meant by ""the DB wouldn't be controllable by any particular entity"")</p>
",1349146456,12683946,False,"<p>if I wanted to create a distributed database for media files (say, images), what would I use?</p>

<p>The idea is that the DB wouldn't be controllable by any particular entity (though the software would be, though it's GPL / forkable).</p>

<p>Instead, you'd have a client which has something like libtorrent and can be used to browse / cache the database.   You'd configure the client with a list of 'sources'.   </p>

<p>Cydia is a good model for this. </p>

<p>Though instead of using web hosts, I'd like to use bit torrent seeders that act as super nodes (which would catalog sub nodes of arbitrary tree height)</p>

<p>Would libtorrent be the best way to go?  Or would there be a better alternative?</p>
",1349059407,0,database distributed bittorrent libtorrent,What would you use to build a distributed database with client?,1444766

12666982,"<p>A much better question.</p>

<p>It's best to keep links to external scripts in your HTML, it's perfectly fine to have a few <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tags. Especially ones using a CDN!</p>

<p>You can move your <code>document.ready()</code> function to external JS, where all of your other JS is kept. But sometimes it's easier to include small snippets like that directly in pages where it concerns only that page.</p>

<p>When moving things to separate files, it's important to include them in the right order.<br>
Usually something like Modernizr at the top (<code>&lt;head&gt;</code>), with jQuery near the bottom (just before <code>&lt;/body&gt;</code>), followed by your plugins, followed by your custom scripts.</p>

12666999,"<p>Don't roll your own parser if the parsing is at all complex. There are lots of options, ranging from the old standby lex/yacc (or flex/bison) to Boost::Spirit to ANTLR. Lex/yacc is a LALR parser and it generates code. The generated code is a bit hard to follow and debug. Boost::Spirit is much more in line with modern programming concepts, as is ANTLR. The basic idea is that you specify the grammar and how that grammar is to be processed.</p>

",1349059859,0,c++ class inheritance polymorphism derived,C++: Using inheritance when not all of the derived classes are known up front?,774499
12667001,"<p>Two things to address here:</p>

<p>First, Dart doesn't have prototypes or prototypal inheritance, and instead uses classical inheritance. Rather than a prototype, objects have a class, and instead of a prototype chain, objects have an super classes.</p>

<p>Second, for your specific case, I think we'd have to see more of what you need to do to figure out the idiomatic way to do it in Dart. It should soon be possible to emulate functions with objects so that you an invoke an object and still have state and other methods associated with it.</p>

<p>See this article for more: <a href=""http://www.dartlang.org/articles/emulating-functions/"" rel=""nofollow"">http://www.dartlang.org/articles/emulating-functions/</a></p>

<p>When that capability lands you'll be able to do this:</p>

<pre><code>class DoStuff {
  bool isDefined = true;
  call() =&gt; print(""The function doStuff was called!"");
}
var doStuff = new DoStuff();

main() =&gt; doStuff();
</code></pre>

<p>Which works if you have a fixed set of metadata about your function that you need to keep track of. It's slightly different from the JavaScript because each instance of the function is Dart will have it's own state for <code>isDefined</code>. I'm not sure if it's possible or easy to get multiple instances of the function is JavasScript, but you might need to make <code>isDefined</code> static so that the value is shared across all instances.</p>
",1349068232,12667793,False,"<p>In Dart, is it possible for a function to have a prototype associated with it?</p>

<p>Example Javascript code:</p>

<pre><code>doStuff.prototype.isDefined = true; //is there anything like Javascript's function prototypes in Dart?
function doStuff(){
    console.log(""The function doStuff was called!"");
}
</code></pre>

<p>Is it possible to do the equivalent of this in Dart (i.e., create a list of properties for each function?)</p>
",1349059874,1,dart,"Does the Dart programming language have an equivalent to Javascript's ""prototype""?",192153
12667003,"<p>You can copy the contents of the URL into a <code>ByteArrayOutputStream</code> and close the URL Stream. Then store the <code>ByteArrayInputStream</code> in the queue.</p>

<p>Pseudo Code : </p>

<pre><code>InputStream in = null;
try {
    in = url.openStream();
    ByteArrayOutputStream buffer = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
    IOUtils.copy(in, buffer);

    ByteArrayInputStream bin = new ByteArrayInputStream(buffer.toByteArray());
    queue.put(bin);
}
</code></pre>

<p>References : </p>

<ol>
<li><a href=""http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/io/ByteArrayInputStream.html"" rel=""nofollow"">java.io.ByteArrayInputStream</a></li>
<li><a href=""http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/io/ByteArrayOutputStream.html"" rel=""nofollow"">java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream</a></li>
<li><a href=""http://commons.apache.org/io/api-1.4/org/apache/commons/io/IOUtils.html"" rel=""nofollow"">org.apache.commons.io.IOUtils.IOUtils</a></li>
</ol>
",1349070768,12668122,True,"<p>I have a kind of tricky problem involving multi-threading. What I do is that I use a thread pool (<code>ExecutorService</code>) that is tasked with opening connections and putting them in a <code>LinkedBlockingQueue</code>.</p>

<p>So far I have used:</p>

<pre><code>//run method in ""getter threads""
public void run() {

    try {

    URL url = new URL(url_s); //url_s is given as a constructor argument

    //if I am correct then url.openStream will wait until we have the content
    InputStream stream = url.openStream();

    Request req = new Request(); //a class with two variables:
    req.html_stream = new InputSource(stream);
    req.source = stream;

    //this is a class variable (LinkedBlockingQueue&lt;Request&gt;)
    blocking_queue.put(req);

    } catch  (Exception ex) {
    logger.info(""Getter thread died from an exeption"",ex);
    return;
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>I then have consumer thread (java.lang.Thread) that takes these <code>InputSource</code>s and <code>InputStream</code>s and does:</p>

<pre><code>public void run() {
   while(running) {
        try {
            logger.info(""waiting for data to eat"");
            Request req = blocking_queue.take();
            if(req.html_stream != null)
            eat_data(req);
        } catch (Exception ex) {
            logger.error(ex);
            return;
        }
   }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Where eat_data calls an external library that takes InputSource. The library uses a singleton instance to do the processing so I cant put this step in the ""getter"" threads.</p>

<p>When I tested this code for small amounts of data it worked fine, but when I supplied it with several thousands of URLs I started to have real problems. ",1349059875,3,c++ abstract-class abstract,"C++ ""Cannot declare parameter to be of abstract type",1710581
12667008,"<p>All the 'excess' code you see is specific to debug builds (and generally gets optimized away for release builds) and allows you to perform something that you can't ordinarily do in release build.</p>

<p>Debug build code is such that it allows maximum independence in setting up breakpoints and changing/examining stack values during a debug session. Also the IL code should mimic the higher level code as far as possible so that every 'cause' and 'effect' can be mapped to higher level code lines.</p>

<p>Now to be specific to your questions:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>What is the purpose of the nop operations in the original?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>NOP allows you to set breakpoints at places which are not 'executed'. For e.g. the opening braces of a method, loop or if statement. Among these non-executable instructions, breaking at the opening brace allows you to modify/examine stack just before a block starts (though admittedly you can achieve this very easily by breaking at the first line of execution of the block instead of opening brace but it still allows you independence of breaking at the opening brace)</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>What is the purpose of the br.s at the end of the methods in the original?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Looking at the original code, you might find it to be nonsensical to 'jump' to the next line instead of allowing the code to naturally 'fall' to the next line. But read it as:</p>

<p>""In a debug build, whenever a method needs to return, jump to the end of the method, read the return value from stack and then return the value""</p>

<p>So what advantage does it offer to debugging?</p>

<p>If you have more than one return statement in your code, both of them will 'jump' to the end of the code before reading the return value from stack. This allows you exactly one place (the closing brace of the method) where you can put a break-point and modify the return value before it is actually returned to the calling method. Pretty helpful isn't it?</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Is the re-written version improper in any way?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>There is nothing improper in your code. In fact if you build the original in release mode and check generated CIL, you will notice that it is mostly same as yours.</p>
",1349093097,12672909,True,"<p>I just started looking at IL a bit and I'm curious if my attempt (shown below) to remove excess code from the output of the compiler had any unintended side effects.</p>

<p>A couple of quesiton about the results:</p>

<ol>
<li>What is the purpose of the nop operations in the original?</li>
<li>What is the purpose of the br.s at the end of the methods in the original?</li>
<li>Is the re-written version improper in any way?</li>
</ol>

<p>Original C# Code:</p>

<pre><code>class Program {
    public static int Main() {
        return Add(1, 2);
    }
    public static int Add(int a, int b) {
        return a + b;
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Compiled with <code>csc.exe</code> and disassembled it with <code>ildasm.exe</code> (Original):</p>

<pre><code>  .method public hidebysig static int32  Main() cil managed
  {
    .entrypoint
    .maxstack  2
    .locals init (int32 V_0)
    IL_0000:  nop
    IL_0001:  ldc.i4.1
    IL_0002:  ldc.i4.2
    IL_0003:  call       int32 Program::Add(int32, int32)
    IL_0008:  stloc.0
    IL_0009:  br.s       IL_000b
    IL_000b:  ldloc.0
    IL_000c:  ret
  } 
  .method public hidebysig static int32  Add(int32 a,
                                             int32 b) cil managed
  {
    .maxstack  2
    .locals init (int32 V_0)
    IL_0000:  nop
    IL_0001:  ldarg.0
    IL_0002:  ldarg.1
    IL_0003:  add
    IL_0004:  stloc.0
    IL_0005:  br.s       IL_0007
    IL_0007:  ldloc.0
    IL_0008:  ret
  }
</code></pre>

<p>Re-written (produces identical output):</p>

<pre><code>  .method public hidebysig static int32  Main() cil managed
  {
    .entrypoint
        .maxstack  2
    ldc.i4.1
    ldc.i4.2
    call int32 Program::Add(int32, int32)
    ret
  }

  .method public hidebysig static int32  Add(int32 a, int32 b) cil managed
  {
    .maxstack  2
      ldarg.0
      ldarg.1
    add
    ret
  }
</code></pre>
",1349059957,3,c# il,Questions about hand coded IL based on disassembled simple C# code,1479080
12667012,"<p>I cant see a problem with a child when I kill it from shell:</p>

<pre><code>test]$ ./a.out 120
PID : 7406 with PPID : 7035 executing for 120 seconds

Parent process: PID= 7490,PPID=7035, CPID=7491

<blockquote>
  <p>My problem is when i use control -c to the father process. It gets the
  interrupt but the message from the handler that the child got the
  message does not appear – Giannos 9 mins ago</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The problem is that you get SIGINT in your child process.
Try to add a handler for SIGINT in the child, then run your test.</p>

<p>You can see what happens with your current implementation after you pressed ctrl-c:</p>

<pre><code>serge    7685  7035 99 08:01 pts/3    00:00:08 ./a.out 1
serge    7686  7685 30 08:01 pts/3    00:00:02 [Child.out] &lt;defunct&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>Your child process got SIGINT and terminated. Also, it is necessary to handle the SIGCLD in the parent to get rid of all your children processes in a defunct state:</p>

<pre><code>if (sig == SIGCLD)
{
   // harvest terminated DEFUNCT child process
   pid = waitpid(-1, &amp;status, WNOHANG);
}
</code></pre>

",1349059991,1,c# wcf service,Push data to client without using CallBack in WCF,387058
12667030,"<p>Solution:  close <code>fd[0]</code> and <code>fd[1]</code> in the parent.</p>

<p>In the twin fork model, which you want, your parent process (the shell) is keeping its copy of <code>fd[1]</code> open.  With this open, the child <code>pid2</code> will never see EOF on its standard input fd.</p>

<p>Comments:</p>

<ol>
<li>both children should close their pipe fds after dup2'ing</li>
<li>the code after <code>execvp</code>, both above and in your <em>pastie</em> suggests that you think that <code>execvp</code> will return control under ordinary circumstances.  It does not.  For this code, at most you probably want to follow the <code>execvp</code> with a <code>perror</code> and <code>exit</code>.</li>
</ol>

12667036,"<p>With that form of <code>default_scope</code>, your <code>Log.get_subject_id</code> call will be evaluated when the class is parsed so you're really saying something like this:</p>

<pre><code>default_scope where(:subject_id =&gt; 0)
</code></pre>

12667048,"<p>Give <a href=""http://us.php.net/preg_replace"" rel=""nofollow""><code>preg_replace</code></a> with the <a href=""http://us.php.net/manual/en/reference.pcre.pattern.modifiers.php"" rel=""nofollow""><code>/e</code> modifier</a> a whirl. Combine that with <a href=""http://php.net/manual/en/language.variables.variable.php"" rel=""nofollow"">variable variable name syntax</a> to get the effect you want.</p>

<pre><code>$page_content = preg_replace('/\[(.*?)\]/e', '$$1', $page_content);
</code></pre>

<p>This uses a regex to match strings between square brackets. The strings are captured and are accessed with <code>$1</code> in the replacement string. The second <code>$</code> looks up the variable named with whatever's in <code>$1</code>.</p>

<p>If you want to do something more complicated with the replacement, you can invoke your own function from the replacement string. For example:</p>

<pre><code>function substitute_tag($tag_name)
{
    $replacement_values = array('foo' =&gt; 'bar', 'baz' =&gt; '42', ...);
    return $replacement_values[$tag_name];
}

$page_content = preg_replace('/\[(.*?)\]/e', 'substitute_tag(""$1"")', $page_content);
</code></pre>

",1349060422,1,uiimagepickercontroller ios6 uipopovercontroller,presentPopoverFromRect:inView:permittedArrowDirections:animated crashing in iOS 6.0,1074338
12667052,"<p>Your problem is not with <code>at()</code>.  Your problem is that you're storing away an address to a local variable, and then later you're using that pointer, even though the local variable doesn't exist anymore.</p>

<p>Specifically, in <code>loadInventory</code>, here's one example:</p>

<pre><code> if (line.compare(""Paperback"") == 0) {
                ty = ""Paperback"";
                getline(ifs, line);
                ti = line;
                getline(ifs, line);
                au = line;
                getline(ifs, line);
                pri = line;
                Paperback p(ty, ti, au, pri);
                inventory.push_back(&amp;p);
            }
</code></pre>

<p>Note in the second-to-last line how you create a local (stack) variable named ""p"".  In the last line, you take the address of that local variable and store it away.  Once the code hits that final brace in the above quote, the variable named ""p"" goes away, and that pointer in your vector is no good anymore.</p>

<p>One possible solution is to dynamically allocate:</p>

<pre><code>Paperback* p = new Paperback(ty, ti, au, pri);
inventory.push_back(p);
</code></pre>

<p>Note that if you do this, you'll have to delete those pointers yourself once your <code>inventory</code> vector is done with them.</p>
",1349061152,12667113,False,"<p>I am creating an application to keep track of a bookstore inventory. It will take the filepath to a text file containing the information as an argument to main. The problem I am having seems to be whenever I attempt to access an element of the class state vector inventory that I am using to store my Item objects. First is the class header, followed by the method definitions, and then the main. Thanks in advance.</p>

<pre><code>    #ifndef _BOOKSTORE_H_
    #define _BOOKSTORE_H_

    #include &lt;vector&gt;
    #include &lt;iostream&gt;

    #include ""Item.h""
    #include ""Paperback.h""
    #include ""Hardcover.h""
    #include ""Audiobook.h""
    #include ""Ebook.h""

    using namespace std;

    class Bookstore {

    //States
    private:
        vector&lt;Item*&gt; inventory;
    //Behaviors
    public: 
        Bookstore();
        void loadInventory(const char*);
        void searchInventory(string);

    #include ""Bookstore.h""

    Bookstore::Bookstore() {}

    void Bookstore::loadInventory(const char* filepath) {

        string ty = """";
        string ti = """";
        string au = """";
        string pri = """";
        string f = """";
        string cd = """";
        string pro = """";

        string line;
        ifstream ifs;
        ifs.open (filepath);

        if (ifs.is_open()) {
            while (ifs.good()) {
                ty = """";
                ti = """";
                au = """";
                pri = """";
                f = """";
                cd = """";
                pro = """";

                getline(ifs, line);

                if (line.compare(""Paperback"") == 0) {
                    ty = ""Paperback"";
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    ti = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    au = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    pri = line;
                    Paperback p(ty, ti, au, pri);
                    inventory.push_back(&amp;p);
                }

                if (line.compare(""Hardcover"") == 0) {
                    ty = ""Hardcover"";
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    ti = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    au = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    pri = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    f = line;
                    Hardcover h(ty, ti, au, pri, f);
                    inventory.push_back(&amp;h);
                }

                if (line.compare(""Audio"") == 0) {
                    ty = ""Audio"";
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    ti = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    au = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    pri = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    cd = line;
                    Audiobook a(ty, ti, au, pri, cd);
                    inventory.push_back(&amp;a);
                }

                if (line.compare(""Electronic"") == 0) {
                    ty = ""Electronic"";
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    ti = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    au = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    pri = line;
                    getline(ifs, line);
                    pro = line;
                    Ebook e(ty, ti, au, pri, pro);
                    inventory.push_back(&amp;e);            
                }

            }
        }

        ifs.close();
        cout &lt;&lt; inventory.size() &lt;&lt; endl;

        for (unsigned int i=0; i&lt;inventory.size(); i++) {
            inventory.at(i)-&gt;printItem();
        }
    }

    void Bookstore::searchInventory(string query) {

        vector&lt;string&gt; searchStr;
        int count;
        string currentStr;

            for (unsigned int i=0; i&lt;inventory.size(); i++) {

                    currentStr = inventory.at(i)-&gt;getTitle();
                    searchStr = split(currentStr);

                    for(unsigned int j = 0; j &lt; searchStr.size(); j++) {
                        if (searchStr[j].compare(query)==0) {
                            inventory.at(i)-&gt;printItem();
                            count++;
                        }
                    }

                    currentStr = inventory.at(i)-&gt;getAuthor();
                    searchStr = split(currentStr);

                    for(unsigned int j = 0; j &lt; searchStr.size(); j++) {
                        if (searchStr[j].compare(query)==0) {
                            inventory.at(i)-&gt;printItem();
                            count++;
                        }
                    }

                    if ((i==(inventory.size()-1))&amp;&amp;(count==0)) {
                        cout &lt;&lt; ""Sorry, no matching results were found."" &lt;&lt; endl;
                    } else if ((i==(inventory.size()-1))&amp;&amp;(count!=0)) {
                        cout &lt;&lt; ""Query complete."" &lt;&lt; endl;
                    }
            }
    }

    unsigned int Bookstore::inventorySize() {
        unsigned int num = inventory.size();
        return num;
    }

    void Bookstore::printInventory() {
        for (unsigned int i = 0; i &lt; inventory.size(); i++) {
            inventory.at(i)-&gt;printItem();       
        }

    }

    vector&lt;string&gt; Bookstore::split(string s) {
        vector&lt;string&gt; pieces;
        istringstream iss(s);
        copy(istream_iterator&lt;string&gt;(iss), istream_iterator&lt;string&gt;(),
            back_inserter&lt;vector&lt;string&gt; &gt;(pieces));

        return pieces;
    }

    #include ""Bookstore.h""

    int main(int argc, char** argv) {

        Bookstore current;

        if (argc==2) {
            current.loadInventory(argv[1]);
        }

        cout &lt;&lt; current.inventorySize() &lt;&lt; endl;

        //Initialize variables
        char status = 'R';
        string input = """";
        int iter = 1;

        //Run application until quit
        while (status=='R') {

            //Provide menu
            if (iter==1) {
                cout &lt;&lt; ""Welcome to Bookstore Inventory 9000."" &lt;&lt; endl;
            }

            if (current.inventorySize()==0) {
                    cout &lt;&lt; ""There are no entries!"" &lt;&lt; endl;
                    status = 'Q';
            } else {

                cout &lt;&lt; ""Would you like to (V)iew all, (S)earch, or (Q)uit?"" &lt;&lt; endl;

                getline(cin, input);

                if (input.compare(""V"")==0) {
                    current.printInventory();       
                } else if (input.compare(""S"")==0) {
                    cout &lt;&lt; endl;
                    cout &lt;&lt; ""What are you looking for?"" &lt;&lt; endl;
                    getline(cin, input);
                    current.searchInventory(input);
                    cout &lt;&lt; endl;
                } else if (input.compare(""Q"")==0) {
                    status = 'Q';
                    cout &lt;&lt; ""Thank you for perusing our inventory. Goodbye."" &lt;&lt; endl;
                } else {
                    cout &lt;&lt; endl;
                    cout &lt;&lt; ""This is not a valid choice. Please try again."" &lt;&lt; endl;
                    cout &lt;&lt; endl;
                }
            }

            iter++;

        }

    return -1;

    }

",1349060896,12667098,False,"<p>I found this sample DB code either on a blog or on SO (don't remember)</p>

<pre><code>package com.learn.db;

import android.content.ContentValues;
import android.content.Context;
import android.database.Cursor;
import android.database.SQLException;
import android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase;
import android.database.sqlite.SQLiteOpenHelper;

public class DBAdapter {

    private static final String DATABASE_NAME = "" nba"";
    private static final String DATABASE_TABLE = ""bookList"";
    private static final int DATABASE_VERSION = 1;
    private static String TAG = ""Upgrading Database!"";
    public static final String KEY_BOOK = ""book"";
    public static final String KEY_AUTHOR = ""author"";
    public static final String KEY_ISBN = ""isbn"";
    public static final String KEY_ROWID = ""_id"";
    public static final String KEY_RATING = ""rating"";
    public static final String KEY_STATUS = ""status"";

    private DatabaseHelper mDbHelper;
    private SQLiteDatabase mDb;

    private static final String DATABASE_CREATE = "" create table  ""
            + DATABASE_TABLE + "" ("" + KEY_ROWID
            + "" integer primary key autoincrement,  "" + KEY_AUTHOR
            + "" text not null, "" + KEY_BOOK + "" text not null, "" + KEY_RATING
            + "" text not null, "" + KEY_STATUS + "" text not null, "" + KEY_ISBN
            + "" text not null); "";

    private final Context mCtx;

    public DBAdapter(Context ctx) {
        this.mCtx = ctx;

    }

    private static class DatabaseHelper extends SQLiteOpenHelper {
        DatabaseHelper(Context context) {
            super(context, DATABASE_NAME, null, DATABASE_VERSION);

        }

        @Override
        public void onCreate(SQLiteDatabase db) {
            db.execSQL(DATABASE_CREATE);

        }

        @Override
        public void onUpgrade(SQLiteDatabase db, int oldVersion, int newVersion) {
            db.execSQL(""ALTER TABLE bookList ADD COLUMN String status"");

        }
    }

    public DBAdapter open() throws SQLException {

        mDbHelper = new DatabaseHelper(mCtx);
        mDb = mDbHelper.getWritableDatabase();
        return this;
    }

    public void close() {
        mDbHelper.close();
    }

    public long createBook(String book, String author, String isbn,
            float rating, String status) {
        ContentValues initialValues = new ContentValues();
        initialValues.put(KEY_BOOK, book);
        initialValues.put(KEY_AUTHOR, author);
        initialValues.put(KEY_ISBN, isbn);
        initialValues.put(KEY_RATING, rating);
        initialValues.put(KEY_STATUS, status);

        return mDb.insert(DATABASE_TABLE, null, initialValues);

    }

    public boolean deleteBook(long rowId) {
        return mDb.delete(DATABASE_TABLE, KEY_ROWID + ""="" + rowId, null) &gt; 0;

    }

    public Cursor fetchAllBooks() {
        return mDb.query(DATABASE_TABLE, new String[] { KEY_BOOK, KEY_ISBN,
                KEY_AUTHOR, KEY_ROWID, KEY_RATING, KEY_STATUS }, null, null,
                null, null, null);
    }

    public Cursor fetchBook(long rowId) throws SQLException {
        Cursor mCursor = mDb.query(DATABASE_TABLE, new String[] { KEY_BOOK,
                KEY_AUTHOR, KEY_ROWID, KEY_ISBN, KEY_RATING, KEY_STATUS },
                KEY_ROWID + ""="" + rowId, null, null, null, null);

        if (mCursor != null) {
            mCursor.moveToFirst();
        }
        return mCursor;

    }

    public boolean updateBook(long rowId, String book, String author,
            String isbn, float rating, String status) {
        ContentValues args = new ContentValues();
        args.put(KEY_BOOK, book);
        args.put(KEY_AUTHOR, author);
        args.put(KEY_ISBN, isbn);
        args.put(KEY_RATING, rating);
        args.put(KEY_STATUS, status);

        return mDb.update(DATABASE_TABLE, args, KEY_ROWID + ""="" + rowId, null) &gt; 0;

    }
}
</code></pre>

",1349060479,2,android database sqlite,Android Sample DB not working,1629707
12667057,"<p>If the presence of the __del__ method is problematic for you, just remove it:</p>

<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; import collections
&gt;&gt;&gt; del collections.OrderedDict.__del__
</code></pre>

<p>You will gain the ability to use OrderedDicts in a reference cycle.  You will lose having the OrderedDict free all its resources immediately upon deletion.</p>
",1349076482,12669066,True,"<p>I want my Python program to be deterministic, so I have been using <code>OrderedDicts</code> extensively throughout the code. Unfortunately, while debugging memory leaks today, I discovered that OrderedDicts have a custom <code>__del__</code> method, making them uncollectable whenever there's a cycle. It's rather unfortunate that there's no warning in the documentation about this.</p>

<p>So what can I do? Is there any deterministic dictionary in the Python standard library that plays nicely with gc? I'd really hate to have to roll my own, especially over a stupid one line function like this.</p>

<p>Also, is this something I should file a bug report for? I'm not familiar with the Python library's procedures, and what they consider a bug.</p>

<p>Edit: <a href=""http://bugs.python.org/issue9825"" rel=""nofollow"">It appears that this is a known bug that was fixed back in 2010. I must have somehow gotten a really old version of 2.7 installed.</a> I guess the best approach is to just include a monkey patch in case the user happens to be running a broken version like me.</p>
",1349060509,2,python garbage-collection ordereddictionary,Python ordered garbage collectible dictionary?,1001643
12667058,"<p>if you think the tree would be too deep and run out of memory, better implement the logic with loop rather than using the recursion.
    temproot=root;
    while(inserted != true){</p>

<pre><code>if(root==null)
    //add at the root.
else if(item&lt;temproot-&gt;item )//it should go to left.
{
    if(temproot-&gt;left==null)
        //add your node here and inserted=true or put break; else just move pointer to   left.
 temproo=temproot-&gt;left; //take left address.

}
else if(it should go to right)
    //check the logic of above if clause.
}//end of while loop
</code></pre>

<p>and if you find that it should go to left and there is no child in left just add your node there.
no need to put all the visited nodes in the system stack because anyway you are not using those nodes.</p>
",1349063080,12667288,False,"<p>I implemented a binary tree data structure. The data structure allows a binary tree to be built from a list (elements are inserted from left to right). How can I optimize insertElement? At the moment, it is recursive, so if tree is deep, it will run out of memory. How can I make it tail-recursive or even end-recursive?</p>

<pre><code>public class Node {

    private int value;
    private boolean isLeaf;

    public Node (int value, boolean isLeaf){
        this.value = value;
        this.isLeaf = isLeaf;
    }

    public int getValue(){
        return value;
    }

    public void setLeaf(boolean value){
        this.isLeaf = value;
    }
    public boolean isLeaf(){
        return isLeaf;
    }

}



public class BinaryTree {

    Node root;
    BinaryTree left_child;
    BinaryTree right_child;

    public BinaryTree(){

    }
    public BinaryTree(Node root, BinaryTree left_child, BinaryTree right_child){
        this.root = root;
        this.left_child = left_child;
        this.right_child = right_child;
    }

    public BinaryTree insertElement(int element){
        if (root==null)
            return new BinaryTree(new Node(element, true), null, null);
        else {
            if (root.isLeaf()){
                root.setLeaf(false);
                if (element &lt; root.getValue())
                    return new BinaryTree(root, new BinaryTree(new Node(element, true), null, null), null);
                else
                    return new BinaryTree(root, null, new BinaryTree(new Node(element, true), null, null));
            } else {
                if (element &lt; root.getValue())
                    if (left_child!=null)
                        return new BinaryTree(root, left_child.insertElement(element), right_child);
                    else
                        return new BinaryTree(root, new BinaryTree(new Node(element, true), null, null), right_child);
                else
                    if (right_child!=null)
                        return new BinaryTree(root, left_child, right_child.insertElement(element));
                    else
                        return new BinaryTree(root, left_child, new BinaryTree(new Node(element, true), null, null));
            }
        }
    }

    public BinaryTree getLeftChild(){
        return left_child;
    }

    public BinaryTree getRightChild(){
        return right_child;
    }

    public void setLeftChild(BinaryTree tree){
        this.left_child = tree;
    }

    public void setRightChild(BinaryTree tree){
        this.right_child = tree;
    }

    public BinaryTree buildBinaryTree(int[] elements){
        if (elements.length==0)
            return null;
        else{
            BinaryTree tree = new BinaryTree(new Node(elements[0], true), left_child, right_child);
            for (int i=1;i&lt;elements.length;i++){
                tree = tree.insertElement(elements[i]);
            }
            return tree;
        }
    }

    public void traversePreOrder(){
        if (root!=null)
            System.out.print(root.getValue() + "" "");
        if (left_child!=null)
            left_child.traversePreOrder();
        if (right_child!=null)
            right_child.traversePreOrder();
    }

    public void traverseInOrder(){
        if (left_child!=null)
            left_child.traverseInOrder();
        if (root!=null)
            System.out.print(root.getValue() + "" "");
        if (right_child!=null)
            right_child.traverseInOrder();
    }
    public void traversePostOrder(){
        if (left_child!=null)
            left_child.traversePostOrder();
        if (right_child!=null)
            right_child.traversePostOrder();
        if (root!=null)
            System.out.print(root.getValue() + "" "");
    }

    public static void main(String[] args){
        int[] elements = new int[]{5,7,2,1,4,6,8};
        BinaryTree tree = new BinaryTree();
        tree = tree.buildBinaryTree(elements);
        tree.traversePreOrder();
        System.out.println();
        tree.traverseInOrder();
        System.out.println();
        tree.traversePostOrder();
        System.out.println();
    }

}
</code></pre>
",1349060518,1,java binary-tree,BinaryTree Data structure with methods,1149024
12667059,"<p>JavaScript doesn't have good support for lookbehinds, but if your format is going to remain the same, you can try something like this:</p>

<pre><code>PATTERN(?!])
</code></pre>

<p>It matches all occurrences of ""PATTERN"" that are not followed by a <code>]</code>.</p>

<p>Let me know if this isn't the case, and I will update my answer to include the check for the opening <code>[</code>.</p>

12667071,"<p>(I'm replying to the question before the edit, because I don't understand exactly what you meant in it).</p>

<p><code>socket.recv</code> is not the best way to wait for data on a socket. The best way I know is to use the <code>select</code> module (documentation <a href=""http://docs.python.org/library/select.html"" rel=""nofollow"">here</a>). The simplest use when waiting for data on a single socket would be <code>select.select([your_socket],[],[])</code>, but it can certainly be used for more complex tasks as well.</p>

<p>Regarding the issue of <code>socket.recv</code> receives an empty string; When the socket is a TCP socket (as it is in your case), this means the socket has been closed by the peer.
Reasons for this may vary, but the important thing to understand is that <strong>after this happens, you will no longer receive any data from this socket</strong>, so the best thing you can do with it is close it (<code>socket.close</code>). If you don't expect it to close, this is where you should search for the problem.</p>

<p>Good luck!</p>
",1349856779,12814847,True,"<p>I have a cluster with 4 nodes and a master server. The master dispatches jobs that may take from 30 seconds to 15 minutes to end.</p>

<p>The nodes are listening with a <code>SocketServer.TCPServer</code> and in the master, I open a connection and wait for the job to end.</p>

<pre><code>def run(nodes, args):
    pool = multiprocessing.Pool(len(nodes))
    return pool.map(load_job, zip(nodes, args))
</code></pre>

<p>the <code>load_job</code> function sends the data with <code>socket.sendall</code> and right after that, it uses <code>socket.recv</code> (The data takes a long time to arrive).</p>

<p>The program runs fine until about 200 or 300 of theses jobs run. When it breaks, the <code>socket.recv</code> receives an empty string and cannot run any more jobs until I kill the node processes and run them again.</p>

<p><strong>How should I wait for the data to come?</strong> Also, error handling in <code>pool</code> is very poor because it saves the error from another process and show without the proper traceback and this error is not so common to repeat...</p>

<hr>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong>:
Now I think this problem has nothing to do with sockets:</p>

<p>After some research, looks like my nodes are opening way to many processes (because they also run their jobs in a <code>multiprocessing.Pool</code>) and somehow they are not being closed!</p>

<p>I found these SO question (<a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6516508/python-multiprocessing-pool-inside-daemon-process"">here</a> and <a href=""http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6428842/zombie-process-in-python-multiprocessing-daemon"">here</a>) talking about zombie processes when using <code>multiprocessing</code> in a daemonized process (exactly my case!).</p>

<p>I'll need to further understand the problem, but for now I'm killing the nodes and restoring them after some time.</p>

12667093,"<p>You aren't setting <code>@users</code> in <code>ProfilesController#show</code>. </p>

<p><code>for object in collection</code> just calls <code>collection.each do |object|</code>, which is why you're getting <code>undefined method 'each' for NilClass</code> (and also why it's generally discouraged to use that syntax, as it creates confusing errors like this one).</p>

<p><strong>profiles_controller.rb</strong></p>

<pre><code>def show
  @users = User.all
  #...
end
</code></pre>
",1349061919,12667172,False,"<p>I want a User(x) to be able to add another User(y) as a friend while User(x) is on User(y's) Profile Page. I set up a has_many_through and everything works except that I can only add a friend from the User Index View. Thank you in advance...The code is below:</p>

<p>The code to the rest is below.</p>

<p>friendship.rb</p>

<pre><code>class Friendship &lt; ActiveRecord::Base
attr_accessible :create, :destroy, :friend_id, :user_id

 belongs_to :user
 belongs_to :friend, :class_name =&gt; ""User""
end
</code></pre>

<p>user.rb</p>

<pre><code>    class User &lt; ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :friendships
  has_many :friends, :through =&gt; :friendships
  has_many :inverse_friendships, :class_name =&gt; ""Friendship"", :foreign_key =&gt;   ""friend_id""
  has_many :inverse_friends, :through =&gt; :inverse_friendships, :source =&gt; :user

  # Include default devise modules. Others available are:
  # :token_authenticatable, :confirmable,
  # :lockable, :timeoutable and :omniauthable
  devise :database_authenticatable, :registerable,
     :recoverable, :rememberable, :trackable, :validatable

  # Setup accessible (or protected) attributes for your model
  attr_accessible :email, :password, :password_confirmation, :remember_me,    :profile_attributes
  # attr_accessible :title, :body



  has_one :profile
  accepts_nested_attributes_for :profile

  before_save do | user |
  user.profile = Profile.new unless user.profile
 end
end
</code></pre>

<p>friendships_controller.rb</p>

<pre><code>class FriendshipsController &lt; ApplicationController
  def create
    @friendship = current_user.friendships.build(:friend_id =&gt; params[:friend_id])
    if @friendship.save
      flash[:notice] = ""Added friend.""
      redirect_to current_user.profile
    else
      flash[:error] = ""Unable to add friend.""
      redirect_to root_url
    end
   end

  def destroy
    @friendship = current_user.friendships.find(params[:id])
    @friendship.destroy
    flash[:notice] = ""Removed friendship.""
    redirect_to current_user.profile
  end
 end
</code></pre>

<p>users_controller.rb</p>

<pre><code>class UsersController &lt; ApplicationController
  def show
    @user = User.find(params[:id])
  end

  def index
    @users = User.all
  end
end
</code></pre>

<p>profiles_controller.rb</p>

<pre><code>class ProfilesController &lt; ApplicationController
  # GET /profiles
  # GET /profiles.json
  def index
    @profiles = Profile.all

    respond_to do |format|
      format.html # index.html.erb
      format.json { render json: @profiles }
    end
  end

  # GET /profiles/1
  # GET /profiles/1.json
  def show
    @user = User.find(params[:id])
    @profile = Profile.find(params[:id])

    respond_to do |format|
      format.html # show.html.erb
      format.json { render json: @profile }
    end
  end

  # GET /profiles/new
  # GET /profiles/new.json
  def new
    @profile = Profile.new

    respond_to do |format|
      format.html # new.html.erb
      format.json { render json: @profile }
    end
  end

  # GET /profiles/1/edit
  def edit
    @user = User.find(params[:id])
    @profile = Profile.find(params[:id])
  end

  # POST /profiles
  # POST /profiles.json
  def create
    @profile = Profile.new(params[:profile])

    respond_to do |format|
      if @profile.save
         format.html { redirect_to @profile, notice: 'Profile was successfully created.' }
         format.json { render json: @profile, status: :created, location: @profile }
      else
        format.html { render action: ""new"" }
         format.json { render json: @profile.errors, status: :unprocessable_entity }
      end
    end
  end

  # PUT /profiles/1
  # PUT /profiles/1.json
  def update
    @profile = Profile.find(params[:id])

    respond_to do |format|
      if @profile.update_attributes(params[:profile])
        format.html { redirect_to @profile, notice: 'Profile was successfully updated.' }
        format.json { head :no_content }
      else
        format.html { render action: ""edit"" }
        format.json { render json: @profile.errors, status: :unprocessable_entity }
      end
    end
  end

  # DELETE /profiles/1
  # DELETE /profiles/1.json
  def destroy
    @profile = Profile.find(params[:id])
    @profile.destroy

    respond_to do |format|
      format.html { redirect_to profiles_url }
      format.json { head :no_content }
    end
  end
 end
</code></pre>

<p>routes.rb</p>

<pre><code>BaseApp::Application.routes.draw do


  resources :friendships

  resources :profiles

  #get ""users/show""

  devise_for :users, :controllers =&gt; { :registrations =&gt; ""registrations"" }
  resources :users

  match '/show', to: 'profile#show'




  match '/signup',  to: 'users#new'

  root to: 'static_pages#home'

  match '/', to: 'static_pages#home'

  . . .
</code></pre>
",1349060834,0,ruby-on-rails-3 devise has-many-through friend user-profile,Creating a Friend While On Their Profile Page,885036
12667099,"<p>If so, then this is the problem. You should do :</p>

<pre><code>holder.txtHighScore.setText(""""+menu.highscore);
</code></pre>

<p>Since <code>menu.highscore</code> is <code>int</code>, it will invoke method <code>setText(int resId)</code> which loads the assossiated resource id that you defined on your <code>strings.xml</code>.</p>

<p>If you put <code>""""+menu.highscore</code>, it will invoke <code>setText(CharSequence text)</code> which is what you want.</p>
